146

149#include <openssl/pem.h>
150#include <openssl/span.h>
151#include <openssl/ssl3.h>

160// NGINX needs this #include. Consider revisiting this after NGINX 1.14.0 has
161// been out for a year or so (assuming that they fix it in that release.) See
162// https://boringssl-review.googlesource.com/c/boringssl/+/21664.
163#include <openssl/hmac.h>
164
165// Forward-declare struct timeval. On Windows, it is defined in winsock2.h and
166// Windows headers define too many macros to be included in public headers.
167// However, only a forward declaration is needed.
168struct timeval;
169
170#if defined(__cplusplus)
171extern "C" {
172#endif
173
174
175// SSL implementation.
176
177
178// SSL contexts.
179//
180// |SSL_CTX| objects manage shared state and configuration between multiple TLS
181// or DTLS connections. Whether the connections are TLS or DTLS is selected by
182// an |SSL_METHOD| on creation.
183//
184// |SSL_CTX| are reference-counted and may be shared by connections across
185// multiple threads. Once shared, functions which change the |SSL_CTX|'s
186// configuration may not be used.
187
188// TLS_method is the |SSL_METHOD| used for TLS connections.
189OPENSSL_EXPORT const SSL_METHOD *TLS_method(void);
190
191// DTLS_method is the |SSL_METHOD| used for DTLS connections.
192OPENSSL_EXPORT const SSL_METHOD *DTLS_method(void);
193
194// TLS_with_buffers_method is like |TLS_method|, but avoids all use of
195// crypto/x509. All client connections created with |TLS_with_buffers_method|
196// will fail unless a certificate verifier is installed with
197// |SSL_set_custom_verify| or |SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify|.
198OPENSSL_EXPORT const SSL_METHOD *TLS_with_buffers_method(void);
199
200// DTLS_with_buffers_method is like |DTLS_method|, but avoids all use of
201// crypto/x509.
202OPENSSL_EXPORT const SSL_METHOD *DTLS_with_buffers_method(void);
203
204// SSL_CTX_new returns a newly-allocated |SSL_CTX| with default settings or NULL
205// on error.
206OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_CTX *SSL_CTX_new(const SSL_METHOD *method);
207
208// SSL_CTX_up_ref increments the reference count of |ctx|. It returns one.
209OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_up_ref(SSL_CTX *ctx);
210
211// SSL_CTX_free releases memory associated with |ctx|.
212OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_free(SSL_CTX *ctx);
213
214
215// SSL connections.
216//
217// An |SSL| object represents a single TLS or DTLS connection. Although the
218// shared |SSL_CTX| is thread-safe, an |SSL| is not thread-safe and may only be
219// used on one thread at a time.
220
221// SSL_new returns a newly-allocated |SSL| using |ctx| or NULL on error. The new
222// connection inherits settings from |ctx| at the time of creation. Settings may
223// also be individually configured on the connection.
224//
225// On creation, an |SSL| is not configured to be either a client or server. Call
226// |SSL_set_connect_state| or |SSL_set_accept_state| to set this.
227OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL *SSL_new(SSL_CTX *ctx);
228
229// SSL_free releases memory associated with |ssl|.
230OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_free(SSL *ssl);
231
232// SSL_get_SSL_CTX returns the |SSL_CTX| associated with |ssl|. If
233// |SSL_set_SSL_CTX| is called, it returns the new |SSL_CTX|, not the initial
234// one.
235OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_CTX *SSL_get_SSL_CTX(const SSL *ssl);
236
237// SSL_set_connect_state configures |ssl| to be a client.
238OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_connect_state(SSL *ssl);
239
240// SSL_set_accept_state configures |ssl| to be a server.
241OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_accept_state(SSL *ssl);
242
243// SSL_is_server returns one if |ssl| is configured as a server and zero
244// otherwise.
245OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_is_server(const SSL *ssl);
246
247// SSL_is_dtls returns one if |ssl| is a DTLS connection and zero otherwise.
248OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_is_dtls(const SSL *ssl);
249
250// SSL_set_bio configures |ssl| to read from |rbio| and write to |wbio|. |ssl|
251// takes ownership of the two |BIO|s. If |rbio| and |wbio| are the same, |ssl|
252// only takes ownership of one reference.
253//
254// In DTLS, |rbio| must be non-blocking to properly handle timeouts and
255// retransmits.
256//
257// If |rbio| is the same as the currently configured |BIO| for reading, that
258// side is left untouched and is not freed.
259//
260// If |wbio| is the same as the currently configured |BIO| for writing AND |ssl|
261// is not currently configured to read from and write to the same |BIO|, that
262// side is left untouched and is not freed. This asymmetry is present for
263// historical reasons.
264//
265// Due to the very complex historical behavior of this function, calling this
266// function if |ssl| already has |BIO|s configured is deprecated. Prefer
267// |SSL_set0_rbio| and |SSL_set0_wbio| instead.
268OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_bio(SSL *ssl, BIO *rbio, BIO *wbio);
269
270// SSL_set0_rbio configures |ssl| to read from |rbio|. It takes ownership of
271// |rbio|.
272//
273// Note that, although this function and |SSL_set0_wbio| may be called on the
274// same |BIO|, each call takes a reference. Use |BIO_up_ref| to balance this.
275OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set0_rbio(SSL *ssl, BIO *rbio);
276
277// SSL_set0_wbio configures |ssl| to write to |wbio|. It takes ownership of
278// |wbio|.
279//
280// Note that, although this function and |SSL_set0_rbio| may be called on the
281// same |BIO|, each call takes a reference. Use |BIO_up_ref| to balance this.
282OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set0_wbio(SSL *ssl, BIO *wbio);
283
284// SSL_get_rbio returns the |BIO| that |ssl| reads from.
285OPENSSL_EXPORT BIO *SSL_get_rbio(const SSL *ssl);
286
287// SSL_get_wbio returns the |BIO| that |ssl| writes to.
288OPENSSL_EXPORT BIO *SSL_get_wbio(const SSL *ssl);
289
290// SSL_get_fd calls |SSL_get_rfd|.
291OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_fd(const SSL *ssl);
292
293// SSL_get_rfd returns the file descriptor that |ssl| is configured to read
294// from. If |ssl|'s read |BIO| is not configured or doesn't wrap a file
295// descriptor then it returns -1.
296//
297// Note: On Windows, this may return either a file descriptor or a socket (cast
298// to int), depending on whether |ssl| was configured with a file descriptor or
299// socket |BIO|.
300OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_rfd(const SSL *ssl);
301
302// SSL_get_wfd returns the file descriptor that |ssl| is configured to write
303// to. If |ssl|'s write |BIO| is not configured or doesn't wrap a file
304// descriptor then it returns -1.
305//
306// Note: On Windows, this may return either a file descriptor or a socket (cast
307// to int), depending on whether |ssl| was configured with a file descriptor or
308// socket |BIO|.
309OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_wfd(const SSL *ssl);
310
311// SSL_set_fd configures |ssl| to read from and write to |fd|. It returns one
312// on success and zero on allocation error. The caller retains ownership of
313// |fd|.
314//
315// On Windows, |fd| is cast to a |SOCKET| and used with Winsock APIs.
316OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_fd(SSL *ssl, int fd);
317
318// SSL_set_rfd configures |ssl| to read from |fd|. It returns one on success and
319// zero on allocation error. The caller retains ownership of |fd|.
320//
321// On Windows, |fd| is cast to a |SOCKET| and used with Winsock APIs.
322OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_rfd(SSL *ssl, int fd);
323
324// SSL_set_wfd configures |ssl| to write to |fd|. It returns one on success and
325// zero on allocation error. The caller retains ownership of |fd|.
326//
327// On Windows, |fd| is cast to a |SOCKET| and used with Winsock APIs.
328OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_wfd(SSL *ssl, int fd);
329
330// SSL_do_handshake continues the current handshake. If there is none or the
331// handshake has completed or False Started, it returns one. Otherwise, it
332// returns <= 0. The caller should pass the value into |SSL_get_error| to
333// determine how to proceed.
334//
335// In DTLS, the caller must drive retransmissions. Whenever |SSL_get_error|
336// signals |SSL_ERROR_WANT_READ|, use |DTLSv1_get_timeout| to determine the
337// current timeout. If it expires before the next retry, call
338// |DTLSv1_handle_timeout|. Note that DTLS handshake retransmissions use fresh
339// sequence numbers, so it is not sufficient to replay packets at the transport.
340//
341// TODO(davidben): Ensure 0 is only returned on transport EOF.
342// https://crbug.com/466303.
343OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_do_handshake(SSL *ssl);
344
345// SSL_connect configures |ssl| as a client, if unconfigured, and calls
346// |SSL_do_handshake|.
347OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_connect(SSL *ssl);
348
349// SSL_accept configures |ssl| as a server, if unconfigured, and calls
350// |SSL_do_handshake|.
351OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_accept(SSL *ssl);
352
353// SSL_read reads up to |num| bytes from |ssl| into |buf|. It implicitly runs
354// any pending handshakes, including renegotiations when enabled. On success, it
355// returns the number of bytes read. Otherwise, it returns <= 0. The caller
356// should pass the value into |SSL_get_error| to determine how to proceed.
357//
358// TODO(davidben): Ensure 0 is only returned on transport EOF.
359// https://crbug.com/466303.
360OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_read(SSL *ssl, void *buf, int num);
361
362// SSL_peek behaves like |SSL_read| but does not consume any bytes returned.
363OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_peek(SSL *ssl, void *buf, int num);
364
365// SSL_pending returns the number of bytes available in |ssl|. It does not read
366// from the transport.
367OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_pending(const SSL *ssl);
368
369// SSL_write writes up to |num| bytes from |buf| into |ssl|. It implicitly runs
370// any pending handshakes, including renegotiations when enabled. On success, it
371// returns the number of bytes written. Otherwise, it returns <= 0. The caller
372// should pass the value into |SSL_get_error| to determine how to proceed.
373//
374// In TLS, a non-blocking |SSL_write| differs from non-blocking |write| in that
375// a failed |SSL_write| still commits to the data passed in. When retrying, the
376// caller must supply the original write buffer (or a larger one containing the
377// original as a prefix). By default, retries will fail if they also do not
378// reuse the same |buf| pointer. This may be relaxed with
379// |SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER|, but the buffer contents still must be
380// unchanged.
381//
382// By default, in TLS, |SSL_write| will not return success until all |num| bytes
383// are written. This may be relaxed with |SSL_MODE_ENABLE_PARTIAL_WRITE|. It
384// allows |SSL_write| to complete with a partial result when only part of the
385// input was written in a single record.
386//
387// In DTLS, neither |SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER| and
388// |SSL_MODE_ENABLE_PARTIAL_WRITE| do anything. The caller may retry with a
389// different buffer freely. A single call to |SSL_write| only ever writes a
390// single record in a single packet, so |num| must be at most
391// |SSL3_RT_MAX_PLAIN_LENGTH|.
392//
393// TODO(davidben): Ensure 0 is only returned on transport EOF.
394// https://crbug.com/466303.
395OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_write(SSL *ssl, const void *buf, int num);
396
397// SSL_KEY_UPDATE_REQUESTED indicates that the peer should reply to a KeyUpdate
398// message with its own, thus updating traffic secrets for both directions on
399// the connection.
400#define SSL_KEY_UPDATE_REQUESTED 1
401
402// SSL_KEY_UPDATE_NOT_REQUESTED indicates that the peer should not reply with
403// it's own KeyUpdate message.
404#define SSL_KEY_UPDATE_NOT_REQUESTED 0
405
406// SSL_key_update queues a TLS 1.3 KeyUpdate message to be sent on |ssl|
407// if one is not already queued. The |request_type| argument must one of the
408// |SSL_KEY_UPDATE_*| values. This function requires that |ssl| have completed a
409// TLS >= 1.3 handshake. It returns one on success or zero on error.
410//
411// Note that this function does not _send_ the message itself. The next call to
412// |SSL_write| will cause the message to be sent. |SSL_write| may be called with
413// a zero length to flush a KeyUpdate message when no application data is
414// pending.
415OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_key_update(SSL *ssl, int request_type);
416
417// SSL_shutdown shuts down |ssl|. It runs in two stages. First, it sends
418// close_notify and returns zero or one on success or -1 on failure. Zero
419// indicates that close_notify was sent, but not received, and one additionally
420// indicates that the peer's close_notify had already been received.
421//
422// To then wait for the peer's close_notify, run |SSL_shutdown| to completion a
423// second time. This returns 1 on success and -1 on failure. Application data
424// is considered a fatal error at this point. To process or discard it, read
425// until close_notify with |SSL_read| instead.
426//
427// In both cases, on failure, pass the return value into |SSL_get_error| to
428// determine how to proceed.
429//
430// Most callers should stop at the first stage. Reading for close_notify is
431// primarily used for uncommon protocols where the underlying transport is
432// reused after TLS completes. Additionally, DTLS uses an unordered transport
433// and is unordered, so the second stage is a no-op in DTLS.
434OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_shutdown(SSL *ssl);
435
436// SSL_CTX_set_quiet_shutdown sets quiet shutdown on |ctx| to |mode|. If
437// enabled, |SSL_shutdown| will not send a close_notify alert or wait for one
438// from the peer. It will instead synchronously return one.
439OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_quiet_shutdown(SSL_CTX *ctx, int mode);
440
441// SSL_CTX_get_quiet_shutdown returns whether quiet shutdown is enabled for
442// |ctx|.
443OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_get_quiet_shutdown(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
444
445// SSL_set_quiet_shutdown sets quiet shutdown on |ssl| to |mode|. If enabled,
446// |SSL_shutdown| will not send a close_notify alert or wait for one from the
447// peer. It will instead synchronously return one.
448OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_quiet_shutdown(SSL *ssl, int mode);
449
450// SSL_get_quiet_shutdown returns whether quiet shutdown is enabled for
451// |ssl|.
452OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_quiet_shutdown(const SSL *ssl);
453
454// SSL_get_error returns a |SSL_ERROR_*| value for the most recent operation on
455// |ssl|. It should be called after an operation failed to determine whether the
456// error was fatal and, if not, when to retry.
457OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_error(const SSL *ssl, int ret_code);
458
459// SSL_ERROR_NONE indicates the operation succeeded.
460#define SSL_ERROR_NONE 0
461
462// SSL_ERROR_SSL indicates the operation failed within the library. The caller
463// may inspect the error queue for more information.
464#define SSL_ERROR_SSL 1
465
466// SSL_ERROR_WANT_READ indicates the operation failed attempting to read from
467// the transport. The caller may retry the operation when the transport is ready
468// for reading.
469//
470// If signaled by a DTLS handshake, the caller must also call
471// |DTLSv1_get_timeout| and |DTLSv1_handle_timeout| as appropriate. See
472// |SSL_do_handshake|.
473#define SSL_ERROR_WANT_READ 2
474
475// SSL_ERROR_WANT_WRITE indicates the operation failed attempting to write to
476// the transport. The caller may retry the operation when the transport is ready
477// for writing.
478#define SSL_ERROR_WANT_WRITE 3
479
480// SSL_ERROR_WANT_X509_LOOKUP indicates the operation failed in calling the
481// |cert_cb| or |client_cert_cb|. The caller may retry the operation when the
482// callback is ready to return a certificate or one has been configured
483// externally.
484//
485// See also |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb| and |SSL_CTX_set_client_cert_cb|.
486#define SSL_ERROR_WANT_X509_LOOKUP 4
487
488// SSL_ERROR_SYSCALL indicates the operation failed externally to the library.
489// The caller should consult the system-specific error mechanism. This is
490// typically |errno| but may be something custom if using a custom |BIO|. It
491// may also be signaled if the transport returned EOF, in which case the
492// operation's return value will be zero.
493#define SSL_ERROR_SYSCALL 5
494
495// SSL_ERROR_ZERO_RETURN indicates the operation failed because the connection
496// was cleanly shut down with a close_notify alert.
497#define SSL_ERROR_ZERO_RETURN 6
498
499// SSL_ERROR_WANT_CONNECT indicates the operation failed attempting to connect
500// the transport (the |BIO| signaled |BIO_RR_CONNECT|). The caller may retry the
501// operation when the transport is ready.
502#define SSL_ERROR_WANT_CONNECT 7
503
504// SSL_ERROR_WANT_ACCEPT indicates the operation failed attempting to accept a
505// connection from the transport (the |BIO| signaled |BIO_RR_ACCEPT|). The
506// caller may retry the operation when the transport is ready.
507//
508// TODO(davidben): Remove this. It's used by accept BIOs which are bizarre.
509#define SSL_ERROR_WANT_ACCEPT 8
510
511// SSL_ERROR_WANT_CHANNEL_ID_LOOKUP indicates the operation failed looking up
512// the Channel ID key. The caller may retry the operation when |channel_id_cb|
513// is ready to return a key or one has been configured with
514// |SSL_set1_tls_channel_id|.
515//
516// See also |SSL_CTX_set_channel_id_cb|.
517#define SSL_ERROR_WANT_CHANNEL_ID_LOOKUP 9
518
519// SSL_ERROR_PENDING_SESSION indicates the operation failed because the session
520// lookup callback indicated the session was unavailable. The caller may retry
521// the operation when lookup has completed.
522//
523// See also |SSL_CTX_sess_set_get_cb| and |SSL_magic_pending_session_ptr|.
524#define SSL_ERROR_PENDING_SESSION 11
525
526// SSL_ERROR_PENDING_CERTIFICATE indicates the operation failed because the
527// early callback indicated certificate lookup was incomplete. The caller may
528// retry the operation when lookup has completed.
529//
530// See also |SSL_CTX_set_select_certificate_cb|.
531#define SSL_ERROR_PENDING_CERTIFICATE 12
532
533// SSL_ERROR_WANT_PRIVATE_KEY_OPERATION indicates the operation failed because
534// a private key operation was unfinished. The caller may retry the operation
535// when the private key operation is complete.
536//
537// See also |SSL_set_private_key_method| and
538// |SSL_CTX_set_private_key_method|.
539#define SSL_ERROR_WANT_PRIVATE_KEY_OPERATION 13
540
541// SSL_ERROR_PENDING_TICKET indicates that a ticket decryption is pending. The
542// caller may retry the operation when the decryption is ready.
543//
544// See also |SSL_CTX_set_ticket_aead_method|.
545#define SSL_ERROR_PENDING_TICKET 14
546
547// SSL_ERROR_EARLY_DATA_REJECTED indicates that early data was rejected. The
548// caller should treat this as a connection failure and retry any operations
549// associated with the rejected early data. |SSL_reset_early_data_reject| may be
550// used to reuse the underlying connection for the retry.
551#define SSL_ERROR_EARLY_DATA_REJECTED 15
552
553// SSL_ERROR_WANT_CERTIFICATE_VERIFY indicates the operation failed because
554// certificate verification was incomplete. The caller may retry the operation
555// when certificate verification is complete.
556//
557// See also |SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify|.
558#define SSL_ERROR_WANT_CERTIFICATE_VERIFY 16
559
560#define SSL_ERROR_HANDOFF 17
561#define SSL_ERROR_HANDBACK 18
562
563// SSL_ERROR_WANT_RENEGOTIATE indicates the operation is pending a response to
564// a renegotiation request from the server. The caller may call
565// |SSL_renegotiate| to schedule a renegotiation and retry the operation.
566//
567// See also |ssl_renegotiate_explicit|.
568#define SSL_ERROR_WANT_RENEGOTIATE 19
569
570// SSL_ERROR_HANDSHAKE_HINTS_READY indicates the handshake has progressed enough
571// for |SSL_serialize_handshake_hints| to be called. See also
572// |SSL_request_handshake_hints|.
573#define SSL_ERROR_HANDSHAKE_HINTS_READY 20
574
575// SSL_error_description returns a string representation of |err|, where |err|
576// is one of the |SSL_ERROR_*| constants returned by |SSL_get_error|, or NULL
577// if the value is unrecognized.
578OPENSSL_EXPORT const char *SSL_error_description(int err);
579
580// SSL_set_mtu sets the |ssl|'s MTU in DTLS to |mtu|. It returns one on success
581// and zero on failure.
582OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_mtu(SSL *ssl, unsigned mtu);
583
584// DTLSv1_set_initial_timeout_duration sets the initial duration for a DTLS
585// handshake timeout.
586//
587// This duration overrides the default of 1 second, which is the strong
588// recommendation of RFC 6347 (see section 4.2.4.1). However, there may exist
589// situations where a shorter timeout would be beneficial, such as for
590// time-sensitive applications.
591OPENSSL_EXPORT void DTLSv1_set_initial_timeout_duration(SSL *ssl,
592 unsigned duration_ms);
593
594// DTLSv1_get_timeout queries the next DTLS handshake timeout. If there is a
595// timeout in progress, it sets |*out| to the time remaining and returns one.
596// Otherwise, it returns zero.
597//
598// When the timeout expires, call |DTLSv1_handle_timeout| to handle the
599// retransmit behavior.
600//
601// NOTE: This function must be queried again whenever the handshake state
602// machine changes, including when |DTLSv1_handle_timeout| is called.
603OPENSSL_EXPORT int DTLSv1_get_timeout(const SSL *ssl, struct timeval *out);
604
605// DTLSv1_handle_timeout is called when a DTLS handshake timeout expires. If no
606// timeout had expired, it returns 0. Otherwise, it retransmits the previous
607// flight of handshake messages and returns 1. If too many timeouts had expired
608// without progress or an error occurs, it returns -1.
609//
610// The caller's external timer should be compatible with the one |ssl| queries
611// within some fudge factor. Otherwise, the call will be a no-op, but
612// |DTLSv1_get_timeout| will return an updated timeout.
613//
614// If the function returns -1, checking if |SSL_get_error| returns
615// |SSL_ERROR_WANT_WRITE| may be used to determine if the retransmit failed due
616// to a non-fatal error at the write |BIO|. However, the operation may not be
617// retried until the next timeout fires.
618//
619// WARNING: This function breaks the usual return value convention.
620//
621// TODO(davidben): This |SSL_ERROR_WANT_WRITE| behavior is kind of bizarre.
622OPENSSL_EXPORT int DTLSv1_handle_timeout(SSL *ssl);
623

628#define SSL3_VERSION_MAJOR 0x03
629
630#define SSL3_VERSION 0x0300
631#define TLS1_VERSION 0x0301
632#define TLS1_1_VERSION 0x0302
633#define TLS1_2_VERSION 0x0303
634#define TLS1_3_VERSION 0x0304
635
636#define DTLS1_VERSION 0xfeff
637#define DTLS1_2_VERSION 0xfefd

639// SSL_CTX_set_min_proto_version sets the minimum protocol version for |ctx| to
640// |version|. If |version| is zero, the default minimum version is used. It
641// returns one on success and zero if |version| is invalid.
642OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_min_proto_version(SSL_CTX *ctx,
643 uint16_t version);
644
645// SSL_CTX_set_max_proto_version sets the maximum protocol version for |ctx| to
646// |version|. If |version| is zero, the default maximum version is used. It
647// returns one on success and zero if |version| is invalid.
648OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_max_proto_version(SSL_CTX *ctx,
649 uint16_t version);
650
651// SSL_CTX_get_min_proto_version returns the minimum protocol version for |ctx|
652OPENSSL_EXPORT uint16_t SSL_CTX_get_min_proto_version(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
653
654// SSL_CTX_get_max_proto_version returns the maximum protocol version for |ctx|
655OPENSSL_EXPORT uint16_t SSL_CTX_get_max_proto_version(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
656
657// SSL_set_min_proto_version sets the minimum protocol version for |ssl| to
658// |version|. If |version| is zero, the default minimum version is used. It
659// returns one on success and zero if |version| is invalid.
660OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_min_proto_version(SSL *ssl, uint16_t version);
661
662// SSL_set_max_proto_version sets the maximum protocol version for |ssl| to
663// |version|. If |version| is zero, the default maximum version is used. It
664// returns one on success and zero if |version| is invalid.
665OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_max_proto_version(SSL *ssl, uint16_t version);
666
667// SSL_get_min_proto_version returns the minimum protocol version for |ssl|. If
668// the connection's configuration has been shed, 0 is returned.
669OPENSSL_EXPORT uint16_t SSL_get_min_proto_version(const SSL *ssl);
670
671// SSL_get_max_proto_version returns the maximum protocol version for |ssl|. If
672// the connection's configuration has been shed, 0 is returned.
673OPENSSL_EXPORT uint16_t SSL_get_max_proto_version(const SSL *ssl);
674
675// SSL_version returns the TLS or DTLS protocol version used by |ssl|, which is
676// one of the |*_VERSION| values. (E.g. |TLS1_2_VERSION|.) Before the version
677// is negotiated, the result is undefined.
678OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_version(const SSL *ssl);

680
681// Options.
682//
683// Options configure protocol behavior.
684
685// SSL_OP_NO_QUERY_MTU, in DTLS, disables querying the MTU from the underlying
686// |BIO|. Instead, the MTU is configured with |SSL_set_mtu|.
687#define SSL_OP_NO_QUERY_MTU 0x00001000L
688
689// SSL_OP_NO_TICKET disables session ticket support (RFC 5077).
690#define SSL_OP_NO_TICKET 0x00004000L
691
692// SSL_OP_CIPHER_SERVER_PREFERENCE configures servers to select ciphers and
693// ECDHE curves according to the server's preferences instead of the
694// client's.
695#define SSL_OP_CIPHER_SERVER_PREFERENCE 0x00400000L
696
697// The following flags toggle individual protocol versions. This is deprecated.
698// Use |SSL_CTX_set_min_proto_version| and |SSL_CTX_set_max_proto_version|
699// instead.
700#define SSL_OP_NO_TLSv1 0x04000000L
701#define SSL_OP_NO_TLSv1_2 0x08000000L
702#define SSL_OP_NO_TLSv1_1 0x10000000L
703#define SSL_OP_NO_TLSv1_3 0x20000000L
704#define SSL_OP_NO_DTLSv1 SSL_OP_NO_TLSv1
705#define SSL_OP_NO_DTLSv1_2 SSL_OP_NO_TLSv1_2
706
707// SSL_CTX_set_options enables all options set in |options| (which should be one
708// or more of the |SSL_OP_*| values, ORed together) in |ctx|. It returns a
709// bitmask representing the resulting enabled options.
710OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_CTX_set_options(SSL_CTX *ctx, uint32_t options);
711
712// SSL_CTX_clear_options disables all options set in |options| (which should be
713// one or more of the |SSL_OP_*| values, ORed together) in |ctx|. It returns a
714// bitmask representing the resulting enabled options.
715OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_CTX_clear_options(SSL_CTX *ctx, uint32_t options);
716
717// SSL_CTX_get_options returns a bitmask of |SSL_OP_*| values that represent all
718// the options enabled for |ctx|.
719OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_CTX_get_options(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
720
721// SSL_set_options enables all options set in |options| (which should be one or
722// more of the |SSL_OP_*| values, ORed together) in |ssl|. It returns a bitmask
723// representing the resulting enabled options.
724OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_set_options(SSL *ssl, uint32_t options);
725
726// SSL_clear_options disables all options set in |options| (which should be one
727// or more of the |SSL_OP_*| values, ORed together) in |ssl|. It returns a
728// bitmask representing the resulting enabled options.
729OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_clear_options(SSL *ssl, uint32_t options);
730
731// SSL_get_options returns a bitmask of |SSL_OP_*| values that represent all the
732// options enabled for |ssl|.
733OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_get_options(const SSL *ssl);

735
736// Modes.
737//
738// Modes configure API behavior.
739
740// SSL_MODE_ENABLE_PARTIAL_WRITE, in TLS, allows |SSL_write| to complete with a
741// partial result when the only part of the input was written in a single
742// record. In DTLS, it does nothing.
743#define SSL_MODE_ENABLE_PARTIAL_WRITE 0x00000001L
744
745// SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER, in TLS, allows retrying an incomplete
746// |SSL_write| with a different buffer. However, |SSL_write| still assumes the
747// buffer contents are unchanged. This is not the default to avoid the
748// misconception that non-blocking |SSL_write| behaves like non-blocking
749// |write|. In DTLS, it does nothing.
750#define SSL_MODE_ACCEPT_MOVING_WRITE_BUFFER 0x00000002L
751
752// SSL_MODE_NO_AUTO_CHAIN disables automatically building a certificate chain
753// before sending certificates to the peer. This flag is set (and the feature
754// disabled) by default.
755// TODO(davidben): Remove this behavior. https://crbug.com/boringssl/42.
756#define SSL_MODE_NO_AUTO_CHAIN 0x00000008L
757
758// SSL_MODE_ENABLE_FALSE_START allows clients to send application data before
759// receipt of ChangeCipherSpec and Finished. This mode enables full handshakes
760// to 'complete' in one RTT. See RFC 7918.
761//
762// When False Start is enabled, |SSL_do_handshake| may succeed before the
763// handshake has completely finished. |SSL_write| will function at this point,
764// and |SSL_read| will transparently wait for the final handshake leg before
765// returning application data. To determine if False Start occurred or when the
766// handshake is completely finished, see |SSL_in_false_start|, |SSL_in_init|,
767// and |SSL_CB_HANDSHAKE_DONE| from |SSL_CTX_set_info_callback|.
768#define SSL_MODE_ENABLE_FALSE_START 0x00000080L
769
770// SSL_MODE_CBC_RECORD_SPLITTING causes multi-byte CBC records in TLS 1.0 to be
771// split in two: the first record will contain a single byte and the second will
772// contain the remainder. This effectively randomises the IV and prevents BEAST
773// attacks.
774#define SSL_MODE_CBC_RECORD_SPLITTING 0x00000100L
775
776// SSL_MODE_NO_SESSION_CREATION will cause any attempts to create a session to
777// fail with SSL_R_SESSION_MAY_NOT_BE_CREATED. This can be used to enforce that
778// session resumption is used for a given SSL*.
779#define SSL_MODE_NO_SESSION_CREATION 0x00000200L
780
781// SSL_MODE_SEND_FALLBACK_SCSV sends TLS_FALLBACK_SCSV in the ClientHello.
782// To be set only by applications that reconnect with a downgraded protocol
783// version; see RFC 7507 for details.
784//
785// DO NOT ENABLE THIS if your application attempts a normal handshake. Only use
786// this in explicit fallback retries, following the guidance in RFC 7507.
787#define SSL_MODE_SEND_FALLBACK_SCSV 0x00000400L
788
789// SSL_CTX_set_mode enables all modes set in |mode| (which should be one or more
790// of the |SSL_MODE_*| values, ORed together) in |ctx|. It returns a bitmask
791// representing the resulting enabled modes.
792OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_CTX_set_mode(SSL_CTX *ctx, uint32_t mode);
793
794// SSL_CTX_clear_mode disables all modes set in |mode| (which should be one or
795// more of the |SSL_MODE_*| values, ORed together) in |ctx|. It returns a
796// bitmask representing the resulting enabled modes.
797OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_CTX_clear_mode(SSL_CTX *ctx, uint32_t mode);
798
799// SSL_CTX_get_mode returns a bitmask of |SSL_MODE_*| values that represent all
800// the modes enabled for |ssl|.
801OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_CTX_get_mode(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
802
803// SSL_set_mode enables all modes set in |mode| (which should be one or more of
804// the |SSL_MODE_*| values, ORed together) in |ssl|. It returns a bitmask
805// representing the resulting enabled modes.
806OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_set_mode(SSL *ssl, uint32_t mode);
807
808// SSL_clear_mode disables all modes set in |mode| (which should be one or more
809// of the |SSL_MODE_*| values, ORed together) in |ssl|. It returns a bitmask
810// representing the resulting enabled modes.
811OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_clear_mode(SSL *ssl, uint32_t mode);
812
813// SSL_get_mode returns a bitmask of |SSL_MODE_*| values that represent all the
814// modes enabled for |ssl|.
815OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_get_mode(const SSL *ssl);
816
817// SSL_CTX_set0_buffer_pool sets a |CRYPTO_BUFFER_POOL| that will be used to
818// store certificates. This can allow multiple connections to share
819// certificates and thus save memory.
820//
821// The SSL_CTX does not take ownership of |pool| and the caller must ensure
822// that |pool| outlives |ctx| and all objects linked to it, including |SSL|,
823// |X509| and |SSL_SESSION| objects. Basically, don't ever free |pool|.
824OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set0_buffer_pool(SSL_CTX *ctx,
825 CRYPTO_BUFFER_POOL *pool);

828// Configuring certificates and private keys.
829//
830// These functions configure the connection's leaf certificate, private key, and
831// certificate chain. The certificate chain is ordered leaf to root (as sent on
832// the wire) but does not include the leaf. Both client and server certificates
833// use these functions.
834//
835// Certificates and keys may be configured before the handshake or dynamically
836// in the early callback and certificate callback.
837
838// SSL_CTX_use_certificate sets |ctx|'s leaf certificate to |x509|. It returns
839// one on success and zero on failure.
840OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_use_certificate(SSL_CTX *ctx, X509 *x509);
841
842// SSL_use_certificate sets |ssl|'s leaf certificate to |x509|. It returns one
843// on success and zero on failure.
844OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_use_certificate(SSL *ssl, X509 *x509);
845
846// SSL_CTX_use_PrivateKey sets |ctx|'s private key to |pkey|. It returns one on
847// success and zero on failure.
848OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_use_PrivateKey(SSL_CTX *ctx, EVP_PKEY *pkey);
849
850// SSL_use_PrivateKey sets |ssl|'s private key to |pkey|. It returns one on
851// success and zero on failure.
852OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_use_PrivateKey(SSL *ssl, EVP_PKEY *pkey);
853
854// SSL_CTX_set0_chain sets |ctx|'s certificate chain, excluding the leaf, to
855// |chain|. On success, it returns one and takes ownership of |chain|.
856// Otherwise, it returns zero.
857OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set0_chain(SSL_CTX *ctx, STACK_OF(X509) *chain);
858
859// SSL_CTX_set1_chain sets |ctx|'s certificate chain, excluding the leaf, to
860// |chain|. It returns one on success and zero on failure. The caller retains
861// ownership of |chain| and may release it freely.
862OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set1_chain(SSL_CTX *ctx, STACK_OF(X509) *chain);
863
864// SSL_set0_chain sets |ssl|'s certificate chain, excluding the leaf, to
865// |chain|. On success, it returns one and takes ownership of |chain|.
866// Otherwise, it returns zero.
867OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set0_chain(SSL *ssl, STACK_OF(X509) *chain);
868
869// SSL_set1_chain sets |ssl|'s certificate chain, excluding the leaf, to
870// |chain|. It returns one on success and zero on failure. The caller retains
871// ownership of |chain| and may release it freely.
872OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set1_chain(SSL *ssl, STACK_OF(X509) *chain);
873
874// SSL_CTX_add0_chain_cert appends |x509| to |ctx|'s certificate chain. On
875// success, it returns one and takes ownership of |x509|. Otherwise, it returns
876// zero.
877OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_add0_chain_cert(SSL_CTX *ctx, X509 *x509);
878
879// SSL_CTX_add1_chain_cert appends |x509| to |ctx|'s certificate chain. It
880// returns one on success and zero on failure. The caller retains ownership of
881// |x509| and may release it freely.
882OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_add1_chain_cert(SSL_CTX *ctx, X509 *x509);
883
884// SSL_add0_chain_cert appends |x509| to |ctx|'s certificate chain. On success,
885// it returns one and takes ownership of |x509|. Otherwise, it returns zero.
886OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_add0_chain_cert(SSL *ssl, X509 *x509);
887
888// SSL_CTX_add_extra_chain_cert calls |SSL_CTX_add0_chain_cert|.
889OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_add_extra_chain_cert(SSL_CTX *ctx, X509 *x509);
890
891// SSL_add1_chain_cert appends |x509| to |ctx|'s certificate chain. It returns
892// one on success and zero on failure. The caller retains ownership of |x509|
893// and may release it freely.
894OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_add1_chain_cert(SSL *ssl, X509 *x509);
895
896// SSL_CTX_clear_chain_certs clears |ctx|'s certificate chain and returns
897// one.
898OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_clear_chain_certs(SSL_CTX *ctx);
899
900// SSL_CTX_clear_extra_chain_certs calls |SSL_CTX_clear_chain_certs|.
901OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_clear_extra_chain_certs(SSL_CTX *ctx);
902
903// SSL_clear_chain_certs clears |ssl|'s certificate chain and returns one.
904OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_clear_chain_certs(SSL *ssl);
905
906// SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb sets a callback that is called to select a certificate.
907// The callback returns one on success, zero on internal error, and a negative
908// number on failure or to pause the handshake. If the handshake is paused,
909// |SSL_get_error| will return |SSL_ERROR_WANT_X509_LOOKUP|.
910//
911// On the client, the callback may call |SSL_get0_certificate_types| and
912// |SSL_get_client_CA_list| for information on the server's certificate
913// request.
914//
915// On the server, the callback will be called after extensions have been
916// processed, but before the resumption decision has been made. This differs
917// from OpenSSL which handles resumption before selecting the certificate.
918OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb(SSL_CTX *ctx,
919 int (*cb)(SSL *ssl, void *arg),
920 void *arg);
921
922// SSL_set_cert_cb sets a callback that is called to select a certificate. The
923// callback returns one on success, zero on internal error, and a negative
924// number on failure or to pause the handshake. If the handshake is paused,
925// |SSL_get_error| will return |SSL_ERROR_WANT_X509_LOOKUP|.
926//
927// On the client, the callback may call |SSL_get0_certificate_types| and
928// |SSL_get_client_CA_list| for information on the server's certificate
929// request.
930//
931// On the server, the callback will be called after extensions have been
932// processed, but before the resumption decision has been made. This differs
933// from OpenSSL which handles resumption before selecting the certificate.
934OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_cert_cb(SSL *ssl, int (*cb)(SSL *ssl, void *arg),
935 void *arg);
936
937// SSL_get0_certificate_types, for a client, sets |*out_types| to an array
938// containing the client certificate types requested by a server. It returns the
939// length of the array. Note this list is always empty in TLS 1.3. The server
940// will instead send signature algorithms. See
941// |SSL_get0_peer_verify_algorithms|.
942//
943// The behavior of this function is undefined except during the callbacks set by
944// by |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb| and |SSL_CTX_set_client_cert_cb| or when the
945// handshake is paused because of them.
946OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t SSL_get0_certificate_types(const SSL *ssl,
947 const uint8_t **out_types);
948
949// SSL_get0_peer_verify_algorithms sets |*out_sigalgs| to an array containing
950// the signature algorithms the peer is able to verify. It returns the length of
951// the array. Note these values are only sent starting TLS 1.2 and only
952// mandatory starting TLS 1.3. If not sent, the empty array is returned. For the
953// historical client certificate types list, see |SSL_get0_certificate_types|.
954//
955// The behavior of this function is undefined except during the callbacks set by
956// by |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb| and |SSL_CTX_set_client_cert_cb| or when the
957// handshake is paused because of them.
958OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t
959SSL_get0_peer_verify_algorithms(const SSL *ssl, const uint16_t **out_sigalgs);
960
961// SSL_get0_peer_delegation_algorithms sets |*out_sigalgs| to an array
962// containing the signature algorithms the peer is willing to use with delegated
963// credentials. It returns the length of the array. If not sent, the empty
964// array is returned.
965//
966// The behavior of this function is undefined except during the callbacks set by
967// by |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb| and |SSL_CTX_set_client_cert_cb| or when the
968// handshake is paused because of them.
969OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t
970SSL_get0_peer_delegation_algorithms(const SSL *ssl,
971 const uint16_t **out_sigalgs);

975OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_certs_clear(SSL *ssl);

983OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_check_private_key(const SSL *ssl);

1011// SSL_CTX_set_signed_cert_timestamp_list sets the list of signed certificate
1012// timestamps that is sent to clients that request it. The |list| argument must
1013// contain one or more SCT structures serialised as a SignedCertificateTimestamp
1014// List (see https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6962#section-3.3) i.e. each SCT
1015// is prefixed by a big-endian, uint16 length and the concatenation of one or
1016// more such prefixed SCTs are themselves also prefixed by a uint16 length. It
1017// returns one on success and zero on error. The caller retains ownership of
1018// |list|.
1019OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_signed_cert_timestamp_list(SSL_CTX *ctx,
1020 const uint8_t *list,
1021 size_t list_len);
1022
1023// SSL_set_signed_cert_timestamp_list sets the list of signed certificate
1024// timestamps that is sent to clients that request is. The same format as the
1025// one used for |SSL_CTX_set_signed_cert_timestamp_list| applies. The caller
1026// retains ownership of |list|.
1027OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_signed_cert_timestamp_list(SSL *ctx,
1028 const uint8_t *list,
1029 size_t list_len);

1031// SSL_CTX_set_ocsp_response sets the OCSP response that is sent to clients
1032// which request it. It returns one on success and zero on error. The caller
1033// retains ownership of |response|.
1034OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_ocsp_response(SSL_CTX *ctx,
1035 const uint8_t *response,
1036 size_t response_len);
1037
1038// SSL_set_ocsp_response sets the OCSP response that is sent to clients which

1045// SSL_SIGN_* are signature algorithm values as defined in TLS 1.3.
1046#define SSL_SIGN_RSA_PKCS1_SHA1 0x0201
1047#define SSL_SIGN_RSA_PKCS1_SHA256 0x0401
1048#define SSL_SIGN_RSA_PKCS1_SHA384 0x0501
1049#define SSL_SIGN_RSA_PKCS1_SHA512 0x0601
1050#define SSL_SIGN_ECDSA_SHA1 0x0203
1051#define SSL_SIGN_ECDSA_SECP256R1_SHA256 0x0403
1052#define SSL_SIGN_ECDSA_SECP384R1_SHA384 0x0503
1053#define SSL_SIGN_ECDSA_SECP521R1_SHA512 0x0603
1054#define SSL_SIGN_RSA_PSS_RSAE_SHA256 0x0804
1055#define SSL_SIGN_RSA_PSS_RSAE_SHA384 0x0805
1056#define SSL_SIGN_RSA_PSS_RSAE_SHA512 0x0806
1057#define SSL_SIGN_ED25519 0x0807

1061// before TLS 1.2.
1062#define SSL_SIGN_RSA_PKCS1_MD5_SHA1 0xff01

1212// Custom private keys.
1213
1214enum ssl_private_key_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
1215 ssl_private_key_success,
1216 ssl_private_key_retry,
1217 ssl_private_key_failure,
1218};
1219
1220// ssl_private_key_method_st (aka |SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD|) describes private
1221// key hooks. This is used to off-load signing operations to a custom,
1222// potentially asynchronous, backend. Metadata about the key such as the type
1223// and size are parsed out of the certificate.
1224struct ssl_private_key_method_st {
1225 // sign signs the message |in| in using the specified signature algorithm. On
1226 // success, it returns |ssl_private_key_success| and writes at most |max_out|
1227 // bytes of signature data to |out| and sets |*out_len| to the number of bytes
1228 // written. On failure, it returns |ssl_private_key_failure|. If the operation
1229 // has not completed, it returns |ssl_private_key_retry|. |sign| should
1230 // arrange for the high-level operation on |ssl| to be retried when the
1231 // operation is completed. This will result in a call to |complete|.
1232 //
1233 // |signature_algorithm| is one of the |SSL_SIGN_*| values, as defined in TLS
1234 // 1.3. Note that, in TLS 1.2, ECDSA algorithms do not require that curve
1235 // sizes match hash sizes, so the curve portion of |SSL_SIGN_ECDSA_*| values
1236 // must be ignored. BoringSSL will internally handle the curve matching logic
1237 // where appropriate.
1238 //
1239 // It is an error to call |sign| while another private key operation is in
1240 // progress on |ssl|.
1241 enum ssl_private_key_result_t (*sign)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len,
1242 size_t max_out,
1243 uint16_t signature_algorithm,
1244 const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
1245
1246 // decrypt decrypts |in_len| bytes of encrypted data from |in|. On success it
1247 // returns |ssl_private_key_success|, writes at most |max_out| bytes of
1248 // decrypted data to |out| and sets |*out_len| to the actual number of bytes
1249 // written. On failure it returns |ssl_private_key_failure|. If the operation
1250 // has not completed, it returns |ssl_private_key_retry|. The caller should
1251 // arrange for the high-level operation on |ssl| to be retried when the
1252 // operation is completed, which will result in a call to |complete|. This
1253 // function only works with RSA keys and should perform a raw RSA decryption
1254 // operation with no padding.
1255 //
1256 // It is an error to call |decrypt| while another private key operation is in
1257 // progress on |ssl|.
1258 enum ssl_private_key_result_t (*decrypt)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out,
1259 size_t *out_len, size_t max_out,
1260 const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
1261
1262 // complete completes a pending operation. If the operation has completed, it
1263 // returns |ssl_private_key_success| and writes the result to |out| as in
1264 // |sign|. Otherwise, it returns |ssl_private_key_failure| on failure and
1265 // |ssl_private_key_retry| if the operation is still in progress.
1266 //
1267 // |complete| may be called arbitrarily many times before completion, but it
1268 // is an error to call |complete| if there is no pending operation in progress
1269 // on |ssl|.
1270 enum ssl_private_key_result_t (*complete)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out,
1271 size_t *out_len, size_t max_out);
1272};
1273
1274// SSL_set_private_key_method configures a custom private key on |ssl|.
1275// |key_method| must remain valid for the lifetime of |ssl|.
1276OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_private_key_method(
1277 SSL *ssl, const SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD *key_method);
1278
1279// SSL_CTX_set_private_key_method configures a custom private key on |ctx|.
1280// |key_method| must remain valid for the lifetime of |ctx|.
1281OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_private_key_method(
1282 SSL_CTX *ctx, const SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD *key_method);
1283
1284// SSL_can_release_private_key returns one if |ssl| will no longer call into the
1285// private key and zero otherwise. If the function returns one, the caller can
1286// release state associated with the private key.
1287//
1288// NOTE: This function assumes the caller does not use |SSL_clear| to reuse
1289// |ssl| for a second connection. If |SSL_clear| is used, BoringSSL may still
1290// use the private key on the second connection.
1291OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_can_release_private_key(const SSL *ssl);

1378
1379// Cipher suite configuration.
1380//
1381// OpenSSL uses a mini-language to configure cipher suites. The language
1382// maintains an ordered list of enabled ciphers, along with an ordered list of
1383// disabled but available ciphers. Initially, all ciphers are disabled with a
1384// default ordering. The cipher string is then interpreted as a sequence of
1385// directives, separated by colons, each of which modifies this state.
1386//
1387// Most directives consist of a one character or empty opcode followed by a
1388// selector which matches a subset of available ciphers.
1389//
1390// Available opcodes are:
1391//
1392// The empty opcode enables and appends all matching disabled ciphers to the
1393// end of the enabled list. The newly appended ciphers are ordered relative to
1394// each other matching their order in the disabled list.
1395//
1396// |-| disables all matching enabled ciphers and prepends them to the disabled
1397// list, with relative order from the enabled list preserved. This means the
1398// most recently disabled ciphers get highest preference relative to other
1399// disabled ciphers if re-enabled.
1400//
1401// |+| moves all matching enabled ciphers to the end of the enabled list, with
1402// relative order preserved.
1403//
1404// |!| deletes all matching ciphers, enabled or not, from either list. Deleted
1405// ciphers will not matched by future operations.
1406//
1407// A selector may be a specific cipher (using either the standard or OpenSSL
1408// name for the cipher) or one or more rules separated by |+|. The final
1409// selector matches the intersection of each rule. For instance, |AESGCM+aECDSA|
1410// matches ECDSA-authenticated AES-GCM ciphers.
1411//
1412// Available cipher rules are:
1413//
1414// |ALL| matches all ciphers.
1415//
1416// |kRSA|, |kDHE|, |kECDHE|, and |kPSK| match ciphers using plain RSA, DHE,
1417// ECDHE, and plain PSK key exchanges, respectively. Note that ECDHE_PSK is
1418// matched by |kECDHE| and not |kPSK|.
1419//
1420// |aRSA|, |aECDSA|, and |aPSK| match ciphers authenticated by RSA, ECDSA, and
1421// a pre-shared key, respectively.
1422//
1423// |RSA|, |DHE|, |ECDHE|, |PSK|, |ECDSA|, and |PSK| are aliases for the
1424// corresponding |k*| or |a*| cipher rule. |RSA| is an alias for |kRSA|, not
1425// |aRSA|.
1426//
1427// |3DES|, |AES128|, |AES256|, |AES|, |AESGCM|, |CHACHA20| match ciphers
1428// whose bulk cipher use the corresponding encryption scheme. Note that
1429// |AES|, |AES128|, and |AES256| match both CBC and GCM ciphers.
1430//
1431// |SHA1|, and its alias |SHA|, match legacy cipher suites using HMAC-SHA1.
1432//
1433// Although implemented, authentication-only ciphers match no rules and must be
1434// explicitly selected by name.
1435//
1436// Deprecated cipher rules:
1437//
1438// |kEDH|, |EDH|, |kEECDH|, and |EECDH| are legacy aliases for |kDHE|, |DHE|,
1439// |kECDHE|, and |ECDHE|, respectively.
1440//
1441// |HIGH| is an alias for |ALL|.
1442//
1443// |FIPS| is an alias for |HIGH|.
1444//
1445// |SSLv3| and |TLSv1| match ciphers available in TLS 1.1 or earlier.
1446// |TLSv1_2| matches ciphers new in TLS 1.2. This is confusing and should not
1447// be used.
1448//
1449// Unknown rules are silently ignored by legacy APIs, and rejected by APIs with
1450// "strict" in the name, which should be preferred. Cipher lists can be long
1451// and it's easy to commit typos. Strict functions will also reject the use of
1452// spaces, semi-colons and commas as alternative separators.
1453//
1454// The special |@STRENGTH| directive will sort all enabled ciphers by strength.
1455//
1456// The |DEFAULT| directive, when appearing at the front of the string, expands
1457// to the default ordering of available ciphers.
1458//
1459// If configuring a server, one may also configure equal-preference groups to
1460// partially respect the client's preferences when
1461// |SSL_OP_CIPHER_SERVER_PREFERENCE| is enabled. Ciphers in an equal-preference
1462// group have equal priority and use the client order. This may be used to
1463// enforce that AEADs are preferred but select AES-GCM vs. ChaCha20-Poly1305
1464// based on client preferences. An equal-preference is specified with square
1465// brackets, combining multiple selectors separated by |. For example:
1466//
1467// [TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256|TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256]
1468//
1469// Once an equal-preference group is used, future directives must be
1470// opcode-less. Inside an equal-preference group, spaces are not allowed.
1471//
1472// TLS 1.3 ciphers do not participate in this mechanism and instead have a
1473// built-in preference order. Functions to set cipher lists do not affect TLS
1474// 1.3, and functions to query the cipher list do not include TLS 1.3
1475// ciphers.
1476
1477// SSL_DEFAULT_CIPHER_LIST is the default cipher suite configuration. It is
1478// substituted when a cipher string starts with 'DEFAULT'.
1479#define SSL_DEFAULT_CIPHER_LIST "ALL"
1480
1481// SSL_CTX_set_strict_cipher_list configures the cipher list for |ctx|,
1482// evaluating |str| as a cipher string and returning error if |str| contains
1483// anything meaningless. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
1484OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_strict_cipher_list(SSL_CTX *ctx,
1485 const char *str);
1486
1487// SSL_CTX_set_cipher_list configures the cipher list for |ctx|, evaluating
1488// |str| as a cipher string. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
1489//
1490// Prefer to use |SSL_CTX_set_strict_cipher_list|. This function tolerates
1491// garbage inputs, unless an empty cipher list results.
1492OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_cipher_list(SSL_CTX *ctx, const char *str);
1493
1494// SSL_set_strict_cipher_list configures the cipher list for |ssl|, evaluating
1495// |str| as a cipher string and returning error if |str| contains anything
1496// meaningless. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
1497OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_strict_cipher_list(SSL *ssl, const char *str);
1498
1499// SSL_set_cipher_list configures the cipher list for |ssl|, evaluating |str| as
1500// a cipher string. It returns one on success and zero on failure.
1501//
1502// Prefer to use |SSL_set_strict_cipher_list|. This function tolerates garbage
1503// inputs, unless an empty cipher list results.
1504OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_cipher_list(SSL *ssl, const char *str);

1507// preference.

1543// unavailable or the peer did not use certificates. This is the unverified list
1544// of certificates as sent by the peer, not the final chain built during
1545// verification. The caller does not take ownership of the result.

1548// |ssl| is a server, the returned chain does not include the leaf certificate.

1550OPENSSL_EXPORT STACK_OF(X509) *SSL_get_peer_cert_chain(const SSL *ssl);

1552// SSL_get_peer_full_cert_chain returns the peer's certificate chain, or NULL if
1553// unavailable or the peer did not use certificates. This is the unverified list
1554// of certificates as sent by the peer, not the final chain built during
1555// verification. The caller does not take ownership of the result.
1556//
1557// This is the same as |SSL_get_peer_cert_chain| except that this function
1558// always returns the full chain, i.e. the first element of the return value
1559// (if any) will be the leaf certificate. In constrast,
1560// |SSL_get_peer_cert_chain| returns only the intermediate certificates if the
1561// |ssl| is a server.
1562OPENSSL_EXPORT STACK_OF(X509) *SSL_get_peer_full_cert_chain(const SSL *ssl);

1564// SSL_get0_peer_certificates returns the peer's certificate chain, or NULL if

1566// of certificates as sent by the peer, not the final chain built during
1567// verification. The caller does not take ownership of the result.

1569// This is the |CRYPTO_BUFFER| variant of |SSL_get_peer_full_cert_chain|.
1570OPENSSL_EXPORT const STACK_OF(CRYPTO_BUFFER) *
1571 SSL_get0_peer_certificates(const SSL *ssl);

1573// SSL_get0_signed_cert_timestamp_list sets |*out| and |*out_len| to point to
1574// |*out_len| bytes of SCT information from the server. This is only valid if
1575// |ssl| is a client. The SCT information is a SignedCertificateTimestampList
1576// (including the two leading length bytes).
1577// See https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6962#section-3.3
1578// If no SCT was received then |*out_len| will be zero on return.

1585// SSL_get0_ocsp_response sets |*out| and |*out_len| to point to |*out_len|
1586// bytes of an OCSP response from the server. This is the DER encoding of an
1587// OCSPResponse type as defined in RFC 2560.
1588//
1589// WARNING: the returned data is not guaranteed to be well formed.
1590OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_get0_ocsp_response(const SSL *ssl, const uint8_t **out,
1591 size_t *out_len);

1593// SSL_get_tls_unique writes at most |max_out| bytes of the tls-unique value
1594// for |ssl| to |out| and sets |*out_len| to the number of bytes written. It
1595// returns one on success or zero on error. In general |max_out| should be at
1596// least 12.
1597//
1598// This function will always fail if the initial handshake has not completed.
1599// The tls-unique value will change after a renegotiation but, since
1600// renegotiations can be initiated by the server at any point, the higher-level
1601// protocol must either leave them disabled or define states in which the
1602// tls-unique value can be read.
1603//
1604// The tls-unique value is defined by
1605// https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5929#section-3.1. Due to a weakness in the
1606// TLS protocol, tls-unique is broken for resumed connections unless the
1607// Extended Master Secret extension is negotiated. Thus this function will
1608// return zero if |ssl| performed session resumption unless EMS was used when
1609// negotiating the original session.
1610OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_tls_unique(const SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out,
1611 size_t *out_len, size_t max_out);
1612
1613// SSL_get_extms_support returns one if the Extended Master Secret extension or
1614// TLS 1.3 was negotiated. Otherwise, it returns zero.
1615OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_extms_support(const SSL *ssl);
1616
1617// SSL_get_current_cipher returns cipher suite used by |ssl|, or NULL if it has
1618// not been negotiated yet.
1619OPENSSL_EXPORT const SSL_CIPHER *SSL_get_current_cipher(const SSL *ssl);
1620
1621// SSL_session_reused returns one if |ssl| performed an abbreviated handshake
1622// and zero otherwise.
1623//
1624// TODO(davidben): Hammer down the semantics of this API while a handshake,
1625// initial or renego, is in progress.
1626OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_session_reused(const SSL *ssl);

1628// SSL_get_secure_renegotiation_support returns one if the peer supports secure
1629// renegotiation (RFC 5746) or TLS 1.3. Otherwise, it returns zero.
1630OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_secure_renegotiation_support(const SSL *ssl);

1632// SSL_export_keying_material exports a value derived from the master secret, as
1633// specified in RFC 5705. It writes |out_len| bytes to |out| given a label and
1634// optional context. (Since a zero length context is allowed, the |use_context|
1635// flag controls whether a context is included.)
1636//
1637// It returns one on success and zero otherwise.

1847
1848// Session caching.
1849//
1850// Session caching allows connections to be established more efficiently based
1851// on saved parameters from a previous connection, called a session (see
1852// |SSL_SESSION|). The client offers a saved session, using an opaque identifier
1853// from a previous connection. The server may accept the session, if it has the
1854// parameters available. Otherwise, it will decline and continue with a full
1855// handshake.
1856//
1857// This requires both the client and the server to retain session state. A
1858// client does so with a stateful session cache. A server may do the same or, if
1859// supported by both sides, statelessly using session tickets. For more
1860// information on the latter, see the next section.
1861//
1862// For a server, the library implements a built-in internal session cache as an
1863// in-memory hash table. Servers may also use |SSL_CTX_sess_set_get_cb| and
1864// |SSL_CTX_sess_set_new_cb| to implement a custom external session cache. In
1865// particular, this may be used to share a session cache between multiple
1866// servers in a large deployment. An external cache may be used in addition to
1867// or instead of the internal one. Use |SSL_CTX_set_session_cache_mode| to
1868// toggle the internal cache.
1869//
1870// For a client, the only option is an external session cache. Clients may use
1871// |SSL_CTX_sess_set_new_cb| to register a callback for when new sessions are
1872// available. These may be cached and, in subsequent compatible connections,
1873// configured with |SSL_set_session|.
1874//
1875// Note that offering or accepting a session short-circuits certificate
1876// verification and most parameter negotiation. Resuming sessions across
1877// different contexts may result in security failures and surprising
1878// behavior. For a typical client, this means sessions for different hosts must
1879// be cached under different keys. A client that connects to the same host with,
1880// e.g., different cipher suite settings or client certificates should also use
1881// separate session caches between those contexts. Servers should also partition
1882// session caches between SNI hosts with |SSL_CTX_set_session_id_context|.
1883//
1884// Note also, in TLS 1.2 and earlier, offering sessions allows passive observers
1885// to correlate different client connections. TLS 1.3 and later fix this,
1886// provided clients use sessions at most once. Session caches are managed by the
1887// caller in BoringSSL, so this must be implemented externally. See
1888// |SSL_SESSION_should_be_single_use| for details.
1889
1890// SSL_SESS_CACHE_OFF disables all session caching.
1891#define SSL_SESS_CACHE_OFF 0x0000
1892
1893// SSL_SESS_CACHE_CLIENT enables session caching for a client. The internal
1894// cache is never used on a client, so this only enables the callbacks.
1895#define SSL_SESS_CACHE_CLIENT 0x0001
1896
1897// SSL_SESS_CACHE_SERVER enables session caching for a server.
1898#define SSL_SESS_CACHE_SERVER 0x0002
1899
1900// SSL_SESS_CACHE_BOTH enables session caching for both client and server.
1901#define SSL_SESS_CACHE_BOTH (SSL_SESS_CACHE_CLIENT | SSL_SESS_CACHE_SERVER)
1902
1903// SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_AUTO_CLEAR disables automatically calling
1904// |SSL_CTX_flush_sessions| every 255 connections.
1905#define SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_AUTO_CLEAR 0x0080
1906
1907// SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_LOOKUP, on a server, disables looking up a session
1908// from the internal session cache.
1909#define SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_LOOKUP 0x0100
1910
1911// SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_STORE, on a server, disables storing sessions in
1912// the internal session cache.
1913#define SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_STORE 0x0200
1914
1915// SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL, on a server, disables the internal session
1916// cache.
1917#define SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL \
1918 (SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_LOOKUP | SSL_SESS_CACHE_NO_INTERNAL_STORE)
1919
1920// SSL_CTX_set_session_cache_mode sets the session cache mode bits for |ctx| to
1921// |mode|. It returns the previous value.
1922OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_session_cache_mode(SSL_CTX *ctx, int mode);
1923
1924// SSL_CTX_get_session_cache_mode returns the session cache mode bits for
1925// |ctx|
1926OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_get_session_cache_mode(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
1927
1928// SSL_set_session, for a client, configures |ssl| to offer to resume |session|
1929// in the initial handshake and returns one. The caller retains ownership of
1930// |session|. Note that configuring a session assumes the authentication in the
1931// session is valid. For callers that wish to revalidate the session before
1932// offering, see |SSL_SESSION_get0_peer_certificates|,
1933// |SSL_SESSION_get0_signed_cert_timestamp_list|, and
1934// |SSL_SESSION_get0_ocsp_response|.
1935//
1936// It is an error to call this function after the handshake has begun.
1937OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_session(SSL *ssl, SSL_SESSION *session);
1938
1939// SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_TIMEOUT is the default lifetime, in seconds, of a
1940// session in TLS 1.2 or earlier. This is how long we are willing to use the
1941// secret to encrypt traffic without fresh key material.
1942#define SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_TIMEOUT (2 * 60 * 60)
1943
1944// SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_PSK_DHE_TIMEOUT is the default lifetime, in seconds, of a
1945// session for TLS 1.3 psk_dhe_ke. This is how long we are willing to use the
1946// secret as an authenticator.
1947#define SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_PSK_DHE_TIMEOUT (2 * 24 * 60 * 60)
1948
1949// SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_AUTH_TIMEOUT is the default non-renewable lifetime, in
1950// seconds, of a TLS 1.3 session. This is how long we are willing to trust the
1951// signature in the initial handshake.
1952#define SSL_DEFAULT_SESSION_AUTH_TIMEOUT (7 * 24 * 60 * 60)
1953
1954// SSL_CTX_set_timeout sets the lifetime, in seconds, of TLS 1.2 (or earlier)
1955// sessions created in |ctx| to |timeout|.
1956OPENSSL_EXPORT uint32_t SSL_CTX_set_timeout(SSL_CTX *ctx, uint32_t timeout);
1957
1958// SSL_CTX_set_session_psk_dhe_timeout sets the lifetime, in seconds, of TLS 1.3
1959// sessions created in |ctx| to |timeout|.
1960OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_session_psk_dhe_timeout(SSL_CTX *ctx,
1961 uint32_t timeout);
1962
1963// SSL_CTX_get_timeout returns the lifetime, in seconds, of TLS 1.2 (or earlier)

2022// SSL_CTX_sess_set_new_cb sets the callback to be called when a new session is
2023// established and ready to be cached. If the session cache is disabled (the
2024// appropriate one of |SSL_SESS_CACHE_CLIENT| or |SSL_SESS_CACHE_SERVER| is
2025// unset), the callback is not called.
2026//
2027// The callback is passed a reference to |session|. It returns one if it takes
2028// ownership (and then calls |SSL_SESSION_free| when done) and zero otherwise. A
2029// consumer which places |session| into an in-memory cache will likely return
2030// one, with the cache calling |SSL_SESSION_free|. A consumer which serializes
2031// |session| with |SSL_SESSION_to_bytes| may not need to retain |session| and
2032// will likely return zero. Returning one is equivalent to calling
2033// |SSL_SESSION_up_ref| and then returning zero.
2034//
2035// Note: For a client, the callback may be called on abbreviated handshakes if a
2036// ticket is renewed. Further, it may not be called until some time after
2037// |SSL_do_handshake| or |SSL_connect| completes if False Start is enabled. Thus
2038// it's recommended to use this callback over calling |SSL_get_session| on
2039// handshake completion.
2040OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_sess_set_new_cb(
2041 SSL_CTX *ctx, int (*new_session_cb)(SSL *ssl, SSL_SESSION *session));
2042
2043// SSL_CTX_sess_get_new_cb returns the callback set by
2044// |SSL_CTX_sess_set_new_cb|.
2045OPENSSL_EXPORT int (*SSL_CTX_sess_get_new_cb(SSL_CTX *ctx))(
2046 SSL *ssl, SSL_SESSION *session);
2047
2048// SSL_CTX_sess_set_remove_cb sets a callback which is called when a session is
2049// removed from the internal session cache.
2050//
2051// TODO(davidben): What is the point of this callback? It seems useless since it
2052// only fires on sessions in the internal cache.
2053OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_sess_set_remove_cb(
2054 SSL_CTX *ctx,
2055 void (*remove_session_cb)(SSL_CTX *ctx, SSL_SESSION *session));
2056
2057// SSL_CTX_sess_get_remove_cb returns the callback set by
2058// |SSL_CTX_sess_set_remove_cb|.
2059OPENSSL_EXPORT void (*SSL_CTX_sess_get_remove_cb(SSL_CTX *ctx))(
2060 SSL_CTX *ctx, SSL_SESSION *session);
2061
2062// SSL_CTX_sess_set_get_cb sets a callback to look up a session by ID for a
2063// server. The callback is passed the session ID and should return a matching
2064// |SSL_SESSION| or NULL if not found. It should set |*out_copy| to zero and
2065// return a new reference to the session. This callback is not used for a
2066// client.
2067//
2068// For historical reasons, if |*out_copy| is set to one (default), the SSL
2069// library will take a new reference to the returned |SSL_SESSION|, expecting
2070// the callback to return a non-owning pointer. This is not recommended. If
2071// |ctx| and thus the callback is used on multiple threads, the session may be
2072// removed and invalidated before the SSL library calls |SSL_SESSION_up_ref|,
2073// whereas the callback may synchronize internally.
2074//
2075// To look up a session asynchronously, the callback may return
2076// |SSL_magic_pending_session_ptr|. See the documentation for that function and
2077// |SSL_ERROR_PENDING_SESSION|.
2078//
2079// If the internal session cache is enabled, the callback is only consulted if
2080// the internal cache does not return a match.
2081OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_sess_set_get_cb(
2082 SSL_CTX *ctx, SSL_SESSION *(*get_session_cb)(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t *id,
2083 int id_len, int *out_copy));
2084
2085// SSL_CTX_sess_get_get_cb returns the callback set by
2086// |SSL_CTX_sess_set_get_cb|.
2087OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *(*SSL_CTX_sess_get_get_cb(SSL_CTX *ctx))(
2088 SSL *ssl, const uint8_t *id, int id_len, int *out_copy);
2089
2090// SSL_magic_pending_session_ptr returns a magic |SSL_SESSION|* which indicates
2091// that the session isn't currently unavailable. |SSL_get_error| will then
2092// return |SSL_ERROR_PENDING_SESSION| and the handshake can be retried later
2093// when the lookup has completed.
2094OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *SSL_magic_pending_session_ptr(void);

2096
2097// Session tickets.
2098//
2099// Session tickets, from RFC 5077, allow session resumption without server-side
2100// state. The server maintains a secret ticket key and sends the client opaque
2101// encrypted session parameters, called a ticket. When offering the session, the
2102// client sends the ticket which the server decrypts to recover session state.
2103// Session tickets are enabled by default but may be disabled with
2104// |SSL_OP_NO_TICKET|.
2105//
2106// On the client, ticket-based sessions use the same APIs as ID-based tickets.
2107// Callers do not need to handle them differently.
2108//
2109// On the server, tickets are encrypted and authenticated with a secret key.
2110// By default, an |SSL_CTX| will manage session ticket encryption keys by
2111// generating them internally and rotating every 48 hours. Tickets are minted
2112// and processed transparently. The following functions may be used to configure
2113// a persistent key or implement more custom behavior, including key rotation
2114// and sharing keys between multiple servers in a large deployment. There are
2115// three levels of customisation possible:
2116//
2117// 1) One can simply set the keys with |SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_keys|.
2118// 2) One can configure an |EVP_CIPHER_CTX| and |HMAC_CTX| directly for
2119// encryption and authentication.
2120// 3) One can configure an |SSL_TICKET_AEAD_METHOD| to have more control
2121// and the option of asynchronous decryption.
2122//
2123// An attacker that compromises a server's session ticket key can impersonate
2124// the server and, prior to TLS 1.3, retroactively decrypt all application
2125// traffic from sessions using that ticket key. Thus ticket keys must be
2126// regularly rotated for forward secrecy. Note the default key is rotated
2127// automatically once every 48 hours but manually configured keys are not.
2128
2129// SSL_DEFAULT_TICKET_KEY_ROTATION_INTERVAL is the interval with which the
2130// default session ticket encryption key is rotated, if in use. If any
2131// non-default ticket encryption mechanism is configured, automatic rotation is
2132// disabled.
2133#define SSL_DEFAULT_TICKET_KEY_ROTATION_INTERVAL (2 * 24 * 60 * 60)
2134
2135// SSL_CTX_get_tlsext_ticket_keys writes |ctx|'s session ticket key material to
2136// |len| bytes of |out|. It returns one on success and zero if |len| is not
2137// 48. If |out| is NULL, it returns 48 instead.
2138OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_get_tlsext_ticket_keys(SSL_CTX *ctx, void *out,
2139 size_t len);
2140
2141// SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_keys sets |ctx|'s session ticket key material to
2142// |len| bytes of |in|. It returns one on success and zero if |len| is not
2143// 48. If |in| is NULL, it returns 48 instead.
2144OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_keys(SSL_CTX *ctx, const void *in,
2145 size_t len);
2146
2147// SSL_TICKET_KEY_NAME_LEN is the length of the key name prefix of a session
2148// ticket.
2149#define SSL_TICKET_KEY_NAME_LEN 16
2150
2151// SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_key_cb sets the ticket callback to |callback| and
2152// returns one. |callback| will be called when encrypting a new ticket and when
2153// decrypting a ticket from the client.
2154//
2155// In both modes, |ctx| and |hmac_ctx| will already have been initialized with
2156// |EVP_CIPHER_CTX_init| and |HMAC_CTX_init|, respectively. |callback|
2157// configures |hmac_ctx| with an HMAC digest and key, and configures |ctx|
2158// for encryption or decryption, based on the mode.
2159//
2160// When encrypting a new ticket, |encrypt| will be one. It writes a public
2161// 16-byte key name to |key_name| and a fresh IV to |iv|. The output IV length
2162// must match |EVP_CIPHER_CTX_iv_length| of the cipher selected. In this mode,
2163// |callback| returns 1 on success and -1 on error.
2164//
2165// When decrypting a ticket, |encrypt| will be zero. |key_name| will point to a
2166// 16-byte key name and |iv| points to an IV. The length of the IV consumed must
2167// match |EVP_CIPHER_CTX_iv_length| of the cipher selected. In this mode,
2168// |callback| returns -1 to abort the handshake, 0 if decrypting the ticket
2169// failed, and 1 or 2 on success. If it returns 2, the ticket will be renewed.
2170// This may be used to re-key the ticket.
2171//
2172// WARNING: |callback| wildly breaks the usual return value convention and is
2173// called in two different modes.
2174OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_ticket_key_cb(
2175 SSL_CTX *ctx, int (*callback)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *key_name, uint8_t *iv,
2176 EVP_CIPHER_CTX *ctx, HMAC_CTX *hmac_ctx,
2177 int encrypt));
2178
2179// ssl_ticket_aead_result_t enumerates the possible results from decrypting a
2180// ticket with an |SSL_TICKET_AEAD_METHOD|.
2181enum ssl_ticket_aead_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
2182 // ssl_ticket_aead_success indicates that the ticket was successfully
2183 // decrypted.
2184 ssl_ticket_aead_success,
2185 // ssl_ticket_aead_retry indicates that the operation could not be
2186 // immediately completed and must be reattempted, via |open|, at a later
2187 // point.
2188 ssl_ticket_aead_retry,
2189 // ssl_ticket_aead_ignore_ticket indicates that the ticket should be ignored
2190 // (i.e. is corrupt or otherwise undecryptable).
2191 ssl_ticket_aead_ignore_ticket,
2192 // ssl_ticket_aead_error indicates that a fatal error occured and the
2193 // handshake should be terminated.
2194 ssl_ticket_aead_error,
2195};
2196
2197// ssl_ticket_aead_method_st (aka |SSL_TICKET_AEAD_METHOD|) contains methods
2198// for encrypting and decrypting session tickets.
2199struct ssl_ticket_aead_method_st {
2200 // max_overhead returns the maximum number of bytes of overhead that |seal|
2201 // may add.
2202 size_t (*max_overhead)(SSL *ssl);
2203
2204 // seal encrypts and authenticates |in_len| bytes from |in|, writes, at most,
2205 // |max_out_len| bytes to |out|, and puts the number of bytes written in
2206 // |*out_len|. The |in| and |out| buffers may be equal but will not otherwise
2207 // alias. It returns one on success or zero on error.
2208 int (*seal)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len, size_t max_out_len,
2209 const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
2210
2211 // open authenticates and decrypts |in_len| bytes from |in|, writes, at most,
2212 // |max_out_len| bytes of plaintext to |out|, and puts the number of bytes
2213 // written in |*out_len|. The |in| and |out| buffers may be equal but will
2214 // not otherwise alias. See |ssl_ticket_aead_result_t| for details of the
2215 // return values. In the case that a retry is indicated, the caller should
2216 // arrange for the high-level operation on |ssl| to be retried when the
2217 // operation is completed, which will result in another call to |open|.
2218 enum ssl_ticket_aead_result_t (*open)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out, size_t *out_len,
2219 size_t max_out_len, const uint8_t *in,
2220 size_t in_len);
2221};

2224// on |ctx|. |aead_method| must remain valid for the lifetime of |ctx|.
2225OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_ticket_aead_method(
2226 SSL_CTX *ctx, const SSL_TICKET_AEAD_METHOD *aead_method);

2228// SSL_process_tls13_new_session_ticket processes an unencrypted TLS 1.3

2231// must call |SSL_SESSION_free| to free it.
2232//
2233// |buf| contains |buf_len| bytes that represents a complete NewSessionTicket
2234// message including its header, i.e., one byte for the type (0x04) and three
2235// bytes for the length. |buf| must contain only one such message.

2243// Elliptic curve Diffie-Hellman.
2244//
2245// Cipher suites using an ECDHE key exchange perform Diffie-Hellman over an
2246// elliptic curve negotiated by both endpoints. See RFC 4492. Only named curves
2247// are supported. ECDHE is always enabled, but the curve preferences may be
2248// configured with these functions.
2249//
2250// Note that TLS 1.3 renames these from curves to groups. For consistency, we
2251// currently use the TLS 1.2 name in the API.
2252
2253// SSL_CTX_set1_curves sets the preferred curves for |ctx| to be |curves|. Each
2254// element of |curves| should be a curve nid. It returns one on success and
2255// zero on failure.
2256//
2257// Note that this API uses nid values from nid.h and not the |SSL_CURVE_*|
2258// values defined below.
2259OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set1_curves(SSL_CTX *ctx, const int *curves,
2260 size_t curves_len);
2261
2262// SSL_set1_curves sets the preferred curves for |ssl| to be |curves|. Each
2263// element of |curves| should be a curve nid. It returns one on success and
2264// zero on failure.
2265//
2266// Note that this API uses nid values from nid.h and not the |SSL_CURVE_*|
2267// values defined below.
2268OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set1_curves(SSL *ssl, const int *curves,
2269 size_t curves_len);
2270
2271// SSL_CTX_set1_curves_list sets the preferred curves for |ctx| to be the
2272// colon-separated list |curves|. Each element of |curves| should be a curve
2273// name (e.g. P-256, X25519, ...). It returns one on success and zero on
2274// failure.
2275OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set1_curves_list(SSL_CTX *ctx, const char *curves);
2276
2277// SSL_set1_curves_list sets the preferred curves for |ssl| to be the
2278// colon-separated list |curves|. Each element of |curves| should be a curve
2279// name (e.g. P-256, X25519, ...). It returns one on success and zero on
2280// failure.
2281OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set1_curves_list(SSL *ssl, const char *curves);
2282
2283// SSL_CURVE_* define TLS curve IDs.
2284#define SSL_CURVE_SECP224R1 21
2285#define SSL_CURVE_SECP256R1 23
2286#define SSL_CURVE_SECP384R1 24
2287#define SSL_CURVE_SECP521R1 25
2288#define SSL_CURVE_X25519 29
2289#define SSL_CURVE_CECPQ2 16696
2290
2291// SSL_get_curve_id returns the ID of the curve used by |ssl|'s most recently
2292// completed handshake or 0 if not applicable.
2293//
2294// TODO(davidben): This API currently does not work correctly if there is a
2295// renegotiation in progress. Fix this.
2296OPENSSL_EXPORT uint16_t SSL_get_curve_id(const SSL *ssl);

2299// the given TLS curve id, or NULL if the curve is unknown.
