2303// Certificate verification.
2304//
2305// SSL may authenticate either endpoint with an X.509 certificate. Typically
2306// this is used to authenticate the server to the client. These functions
2307// configure certificate verification.
2308//
2309// WARNING: By default, certificate verification errors on a client are not
2310// fatal. See |SSL_VERIFY_NONE| This may be configured with
2311// |SSL_CTX_set_verify|.
2312//
2313// By default clients are anonymous but a server may request a certificate from
2314// the client by setting |SSL_VERIFY_PEER|.
2315//
2316// Many of these functions use OpenSSL's legacy X.509 stack which is
2317// underdocumented and deprecated, but the replacement isn't ready yet. For
2318// now, consumers may use the existing stack or bypass it by performing
2319// certificate verification externally. This may be done with
2320// |SSL_CTX_set_cert_verify_callback| or by extracting the chain with
2321// |SSL_get_peer_cert_chain| after the handshake. In the future, functions will
2322// be added to use the SSL stack without dependency on any part of the legacy
2323// X.509 and ASN.1 stack.
2324//
2325// To augment certificate verification, a client may also enable OCSP stapling
2326// (RFC 6066) and Certificate Transparency (RFC 6962) extensions.
2327
2328// SSL_VERIFY_NONE, on a client, verifies the server certificate but does not
2329// make errors fatal. The result may be checked with |SSL_get_verify_result|. On
2330// a server it does not request a client certificate. This is the default.
2331#define SSL_VERIFY_NONE 0x00
2332
2333// SSL_VERIFY_PEER, on a client, makes server certificate errors fatal. On a
2334// server it requests a client certificate and makes errors fatal. However,
2335// anonymous clients are still allowed. See
2336// |SSL_VERIFY_FAIL_IF_NO_PEER_CERT|.
2337#define SSL_VERIFY_PEER 0x01
2338
2339// SSL_VERIFY_FAIL_IF_NO_PEER_CERT configures a server to reject connections if
2340// the client declines to send a certificate. This flag must be used together
2341// with |SSL_VERIFY_PEER|, otherwise it won't work.
2342#define SSL_VERIFY_FAIL_IF_NO_PEER_CERT 0x02
2343
2344// SSL_VERIFY_PEER_IF_NO_OBC configures a server to request a client certificate
2345// if and only if Channel ID is not negotiated.
2346#define SSL_VERIFY_PEER_IF_NO_OBC 0x04
2347
2348// SSL_CTX_set_verify configures certificate verification behavior. |mode| is
2349// one of the |SSL_VERIFY_*| values defined above. |callback|, if not NULL, is
2350// used to customize certificate verification. See the behavior of
2351// |X509_STORE_CTX_set_verify_cb|.
2352//
2353// The callback may use |SSL_get_ex_data_X509_STORE_CTX_idx| with
2354// |X509_STORE_CTX_get_ex_data| to look up the |SSL| from |store_ctx|.
2355OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_verify(
2356 SSL_CTX *ctx, int mode, int (*callback)(int ok, X509_STORE_CTX *store_ctx));
2357
2358// SSL_set_verify configures certificate verification behavior. |mode| is one of
2359// the |SSL_VERIFY_*| values defined above. |callback|, if not NULL, is used to
2360// customize certificate verification. See the behavior of
2361// |X509_STORE_CTX_set_verify_cb|.
2362//
2363// The callback may use |SSL_get_ex_data_X509_STORE_CTX_idx| with
2364// |X509_STORE_CTX_get_ex_data| to look up the |SSL| from |store_ctx|.
2365OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_verify(SSL *ssl, int mode,
2366 int (*callback)(int ok,
2367 X509_STORE_CTX *store_ctx));
2368
2369enum ssl_verify_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
2370 ssl_verify_ok,
2371 ssl_verify_invalid,
2372 ssl_verify_retry,
2373};
2374
2375// SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify configures certificate verification. |mode| is one
2376// of the |SSL_VERIFY_*| values defined above. |callback| performs the
2377// certificate verification.
2378//
2379// The callback may call |SSL_get0_peer_certificates| for the certificate chain
2380// to validate. The callback should return |ssl_verify_ok| if the certificate is
2381// valid. If the certificate is invalid, the callback should return
2382// |ssl_verify_invalid| and optionally set |*out_alert| to an alert to send to
2383// the peer. Some useful alerts include |SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_EXPIRED|,
2384// |SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_REVOKED|, |SSL_AD_UNKNOWN_CA|, |SSL_AD_BAD_CERTIFICATE|,
2385// |SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_UNKNOWN|, and |SSL_AD_INTERNAL_ERROR|. See RFC 5246
2386// section 7.2.2 for their precise meanings. If unspecified,
2387// |SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_UNKNOWN| will be sent by default.
2388//
2389// To verify a certificate asynchronously, the callback may return
2390// |ssl_verify_retry|. The handshake will then pause with |SSL_get_error|
2391// returning |SSL_ERROR_WANT_CERTIFICATE_VERIFY|.
2392OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify(
2393 SSL_CTX *ctx, int mode,
2394 enum ssl_verify_result_t (*callback)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out_alert));
2395
2396// SSL_set_custom_verify behaves like |SSL_CTX_set_custom_verify| but configures
2397// an individual |SSL|.
2398OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_custom_verify(
2399 SSL *ssl, int mode,
2400 enum ssl_verify_result_t (*callback)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out_alert));

2403// |SSL_CTX_set_verify|.
2404OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_get_verify_mode(const SSL_CTX *ctx);
2405
2406// SSL_get_verify_mode returns |ssl|'s verify mode, set by |SSL_CTX_set_verify|
2407// or |SSL_set_verify|. It returns -1 on error.
2408OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_verify_mode(const SSL *ssl);

2413 int ok, X509_STORE_CTX *store_ctx);

2672// Server name indication.
2673//
2674// The server_name extension (RFC 3546) allows the client to advertise the name
2675// of the server it is connecting to. This is used in virtual hosting
2676// deployments to select one of a several certificates on a single IP. Only the
2677// host_name name type is supported.
2678
2679#define TLSEXT_NAMETYPE_host_name 0
2680
2681// SSL_set_tlsext_host_name, for a client, configures |ssl| to advertise |name|
2682// in the server_name extension. It returns one on success and zero on error.
2683OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_tlsext_host_name(SSL *ssl, const char *name);
2684
2685// SSL_get_servername, for a server, returns the hostname supplied by the
2686// client or NULL if there was none. The |type| argument must be
2687// |TLSEXT_NAMETYPE_host_name|.
2688OPENSSL_EXPORT const char *SSL_get_servername(const SSL *ssl, const int type);
2689
2690// SSL_get_servername_type, for a server, returns |TLSEXT_NAMETYPE_host_name|
2691// if the client sent a hostname and -1 otherwise.
2692OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_servername_type(const SSL *ssl);
2693
2694// SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_servername_callback configures |callback| to be called on
2695// the server after ClientHello extensions have been parsed and returns one.
2696// The callback may use |SSL_get_servername| to examine the server_name
2697// extension and returns a |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_*| value. The value of |arg| may be
2698// set by calling |SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_servername_arg|.
2699//
2700// If the callback returns |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_NOACK|, the server_name extension is
2701// not acknowledged in the ServerHello. If the return value is
2702// |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_FATAL|, then |*out_alert| is the alert to send,
2703// defaulting to |SSL_AD_UNRECOGNIZED_NAME|. |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_WARNING| is
2704// ignored and treated as |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK|.
2705OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_servername_callback(
2706 SSL_CTX *ctx, int (*callback)(SSL *ssl, int *out_alert, void *arg));
2707
2708// SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_servername_arg sets the argument to the servername
2709// callback and returns one. See |SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_servername_callback|.
2710OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_servername_arg(SSL_CTX *ctx, void *arg);
2711
2712// SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_* are values returned by some extension-related callbacks.
2713#define SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK 0
2714#define SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_WARNING 1
2715#define SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_FATAL 2
2716#define SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_NOACK 3
2717
2718// SSL_set_SSL_CTX changes |ssl|'s |SSL_CTX|. |ssl| will use the
2719// certificate-related settings from |ctx|, and |SSL_get_SSL_CTX| will report
2720// |ctx|. This function may be used during the callbacks registered by
2721// |SSL_CTX_set_select_certificate_cb|,
2722// |SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_servername_callback|, and |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb| or when
2723// the handshake is paused from them. It is typically used to switch
2724// certificates based on SNI.
2725//
2726// Note the session cache and related settings will continue to use the initial
2727// |SSL_CTX|. Callers should use |SSL_CTX_set_session_id_context| to partition
2728// the session cache between different domains.
2729//
2730// TODO(davidben): Should other settings change after this call?
2731OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_CTX *SSL_set_SSL_CTX(SSL *ssl, SSL_CTX *ctx);

2733
2734// Application-layer protocol negotiation.
2735//
2736// The ALPN extension (RFC 7301) allows negotiating different application-layer
2737// protocols over a single port. This is used, for example, to negotiate
2738// HTTP/2.
2739
2740// SSL_CTX_set_alpn_protos sets the client ALPN protocol list on |ctx| to
2741// |protos|. |protos| must be in wire-format (i.e. a series of non-empty, 8-bit
2742// length-prefixed strings), or the empty string to disable ALPN. It returns
2743// zero on success and one on failure. Configuring a non-empty string enables
2744// ALPN on a client.
2745//
2746// WARNING: this function is dangerous because it breaks the usual return value
2747// convention.
2748OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_alpn_protos(SSL_CTX *ctx, const uint8_t *protos,
2749 unsigned protos_len);
2750
2751// SSL_set_alpn_protos sets the client ALPN protocol list on |ssl| to |protos|.
2752// |protos| must be in wire-format (i.e. a series of non-empty, 8-bit
2753// length-prefixed strings), or the empty string to disable ALPN. It returns
2754// zero on success and one on failure. Configuring a non-empty string enables
2755// ALPN on a client.
2756//
2757// WARNING: this function is dangerous because it breaks the usual return value
2758// convention.
2759OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_alpn_protos(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t *protos,
2760 unsigned protos_len);
2761
2762// SSL_CTX_set_alpn_select_cb sets a callback function on |ctx| that is called
2763// during ClientHello processing in order to select an ALPN protocol from the
2764// client's list of offered protocols.
2765//
2766// The callback is passed a wire-format (i.e. a series of non-empty, 8-bit
2767// length-prefixed strings) ALPN protocol list in |in|. To select a protocol,
2768// the callback should set |*out| and |*out_len| to the selected protocol and
2769// return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK| on success. It does not pass ownership of the
2770// buffer, so |*out| should point to a static string, a buffer that outlives the
2771// callback call, or the corresponding entry in |in|.
2772//
2773// If the server supports ALPN, but there are no protocols in common, the
2774// callback should return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_FATAL| to abort the connection
2775// with a no_application_protocol alert.
2776//
2777// If the server does not support ALPN, it can return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_NOACK| to
2778// continue the handshake without negotiating a protocol. This may be useful if
2779// multiple server configurations share an |SSL_CTX|, only some of which have
2780// ALPN protocols configured.
2781//
2782// |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_WARNING| is ignored and will be treated as
2783// |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_NOACK|.
2784//
2785// The callback will only be called if the client supports ALPN. Callers that
2786// wish to require ALPN for all clients must check |SSL_get0_alpn_selected|
2787// after the handshake. In QUIC connections, this is done automatically.
2788//
2789// The cipher suite is selected before negotiating ALPN. The callback may use
2790// |SSL_get_pending_cipher| to query the cipher suite. This may be used to
2791// implement HTTP/2's cipher suite constraints.
2792OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_alpn_select_cb(
2793 SSL_CTX *ctx, int (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t **out, uint8_t *out_len,
2794 const uint8_t *in, unsigned in_len, void *arg),
2795 void *arg);
2796
2797// SSL_get0_alpn_selected gets the selected ALPN protocol (if any) from |ssl|.
2798// On return it sets |*out_data| to point to |*out_len| bytes of protocol name
2799// (not including the leading length-prefix byte). If the server didn't respond
2800// with a negotiated protocol then |*out_len| will be zero.
2801OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_get0_alpn_selected(const SSL *ssl,
2802 const uint8_t **out_data,
2803 unsigned *out_len);
2804
2805// SSL_CTX_set_allow_unknown_alpn_protos configures client connections on |ctx|
2806// to allow unknown ALPN protocols from the server. Otherwise, by default, the
2807// client will require that the protocol be advertised in
2808// |SSL_CTX_set_alpn_protos|.
2809OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_allow_unknown_alpn_protos(SSL_CTX *ctx,
2810 int enabled);
2811
2812
2813// Application-layer protocol settings
2814//
2815// The ALPS extension (draft-vvv-tls-alps) allows exchanging application-layer
2816// settings in the TLS handshake for applications negotiated with ALPN. Note
2817// that, when ALPS is negotiated, the client and server each advertise their own
2818// settings, so there are functions to both configure setting to send and query
2819// received settings.
2820
2821// SSL_add_application_settings configures |ssl| to enable ALPS with ALPN
2822// protocol |proto|, sending an ALPS value of |settings|. It returns one on
2823// success and zero on error. If |proto| is negotiated via ALPN and the peer
2824// supports ALPS, |settings| will be sent to the peer. The peer's ALPS value can
2825// be retrieved with |SSL_get0_peer_application_settings|.
2826//
2827// On the client, this function should be called before the handshake, once for
2828// each supported ALPN protocol which uses ALPS. |proto| must be included in the
2829// client's ALPN configuration (see |SSL_CTX_set_alpn_protos| and
2830// |SSL_set_alpn_protos|). On the server, ALPS can be preconfigured for each
2831// protocol as in the client, or configuration can be deferred to the ALPN
2832// callback (see |SSL_CTX_set_alpn_select_cb|), in which case only the selected
2833// protocol needs to be configured.
2834//
2835// ALPS can be independently configured from 0-RTT, however changes in protocol
2836// settings will fallback to 1-RTT to negotiate the new value, so it is
2837// recommended for |settings| to be relatively stable.
2838OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_add_application_settings(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t *proto,
2839 size_t proto_len,
2840 const uint8_t *settings,
2841 size_t settings_len);
2842
2843// SSL_get0_peer_application_settings sets |*out_data| and |*out_len| to a
2844// buffer containing the peer's ALPS value, or the empty string if ALPS was not
2845// negotiated. Note an empty string could also indicate the peer sent an empty
2846// settings value. Use |SSL_has_application_settings| to check if ALPS was
2847// negotiated. The output buffer is owned by |ssl| and is valid until the next
2848// time |ssl| is modified.
2849OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_get0_peer_application_settings(const SSL *ssl,
2850 const uint8_t **out_data,
2851 size_t *out_len);
2852
2853// SSL_has_application_settings returns one if ALPS was negotiated on this
2854// connection and zero otherwise.
2855OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_has_application_settings(const SSL *ssl);
2856
2857
2858// Certificate compression.
2859//
2860// Certificates in TLS 1.3 can be compressed (RFC 8879). BoringSSL supports this
2861// as both a client and a server, but does not link against any specific
2862// compression libraries in order to keep dependencies to a minimum. Instead,
2863// hooks for compression and decompression can be installed in an |SSL_CTX| to
2864// enable support.
2865
2866// ssl_cert_compression_func_t is a pointer to a function that performs
2867// compression. It must write the compressed representation of |in| to |out|,
2868// returning one on success and zero on error. The results of compressing
2869// certificates are not cached internally. Implementations may wish to implement
2870// their own cache if they expect it to be useful given the certificates that
2871// they serve.
2872typedef int (*ssl_cert_compression_func_t)(SSL *ssl, CBB *out,
2873 const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
2874
2875// ssl_cert_decompression_func_t is a pointer to a function that performs
2876// decompression. The compressed data from the peer is passed as |in| and the
2877// decompressed result must be exactly |uncompressed_len| bytes long. It returns
2878// one on success, in which case |*out| must be set to the result of
2879// decompressing |in|, or zero on error. Setting |*out| transfers ownership,
2880// i.e. |CRYPTO_BUFFER_free| will be called on |*out| at some point in the
2881// future. The results of decompressions are not cached internally.
2882// Implementations may wish to implement their own cache if they expect it to be
2883// useful.
2884typedef int (*ssl_cert_decompression_func_t)(SSL *ssl, CRYPTO_BUFFER **out,
2885 size_t uncompressed_len,
2886 const uint8_t *in, size_t in_len);
2887
2888// SSL_CTX_add_cert_compression_alg registers a certificate compression
2889// algorithm on |ctx| with ID |alg_id|. (The value of |alg_id| should be an IANA
2890// assigned value and each can only be registered once.)
2891//
2892// One of the function pointers may be NULL to avoid having to implement both
2893// sides of a compression algorithm if you're only going to use it in one
2894// direction. In this case, the unimplemented direction acts like it was never
2895// configured.
2896//
2897// For a server, algorithms are registered in preference order with the most
2898// preferable first. It returns one on success or zero on error.
2899OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_add_cert_compression_alg(
2900 SSL_CTX *ctx, uint16_t alg_id, ssl_cert_compression_func_t compress,
2901 ssl_cert_decompression_func_t decompress);

2904// Next protocol negotiation.
2905//
2906// The NPN extension (draft-agl-tls-nextprotoneg-03) is the predecessor to ALPN
2907// and deprecated in favor of it.
2908
2909// SSL_CTX_set_next_protos_advertised_cb sets a callback that is called when a
2910// TLS server needs a list of supported protocols for Next Protocol
2911// Negotiation. The returned list must be in wire format. The list is returned
2912// by setting |*out| to point to it and |*out_len| to its length. This memory
2913// will not be modified, but one should assume that |ssl| keeps a reference to
2914// it.
2915//
2916// The callback should return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK| if it wishes to advertise.
2917// Otherwise, no such extension will be included in the ServerHello.
2918OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_next_protos_advertised_cb(
2919 SSL_CTX *ctx,
2920 int (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t **out, unsigned *out_len, void *arg),
2921 void *arg);
2922
2923// SSL_CTX_set_next_proto_select_cb sets a callback that is called when a client
2924// needs to select a protocol from the server's provided list. |*out| must be
2925// set to point to the selected protocol (which may be within |in|). The length
2926// of the protocol name must be written into |*out_len|. The server's advertised
2927// protocols are provided in |in| and |in_len|. The callback can assume that
2928// |in| is syntactically valid.
2929//
2930// The client must select a protocol. It is fatal to the connection if this
2931// callback returns a value other than |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK|.
2932//
2933// Configuring this callback enables NPN on a client.
2934OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_next_proto_select_cb(
2935 SSL_CTX *ctx, int (*cb)(SSL *ssl, uint8_t **out, uint8_t *out_len,
2936 const uint8_t *in, unsigned in_len, void *arg),
2937 void *arg);
2938
2939// SSL_get0_next_proto_negotiated sets |*out_data| and |*out_len| to point to
2940// the client's requested protocol for this connection. If the client didn't
2941// request any protocol, then |*out_data| is set to NULL.
2942//
2943// Note that the client can request any protocol it chooses. The value returned
2944// from this function need not be a member of the list of supported protocols
2945// provided by the server.
2946OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_get0_next_proto_negotiated(const SSL *ssl,
2947 const uint8_t **out_data,
2948 unsigned *out_len);
2949
2950// SSL_select_next_proto implements the standard protocol selection. It is
2951// expected that this function is called from the callback set by
2952// |SSL_CTX_set_next_proto_select_cb|.
2953//
2954// |peer| and |supported| must be vectors of 8-bit, length-prefixed byte strings
2955// containing the peer and locally-configured protocols, respectively. The
2956// length byte itself is not included in the length. A byte string of length 0
2957// is invalid. No byte string may be truncated. |supported| is assumed to be
2958// non-empty.
2959//
2960// This function finds the first protocol in |peer| which is also in
2961// |supported|. If one was found, it sets |*out| and |*out_len| to point to it
2962// and returns |OPENSSL_NPN_NEGOTIATED|. Otherwise, it returns
2963// |OPENSSL_NPN_NO_OVERLAP| and sets |*out| and |*out_len| to the first
2964// supported protocol.
2965OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_select_next_proto(uint8_t **out, uint8_t *out_len,
2966 const uint8_t *peer, unsigned peer_len,
2967 const uint8_t *supported,
2968 unsigned supported_len);
2969
2970#define OPENSSL_NPN_UNSUPPORTED 0
2971#define OPENSSL_NPN_NEGOTIATED 1
2972#define OPENSSL_NPN_NO_OVERLAP 2

3093// Pre-shared keys.
3094//
3095// Connections may be configured with PSK (Pre-Shared Key) cipher suites. These
3096// authenticate using out-of-band pre-shared keys rather than certificates. See
3097// RFC 4279.
3098//
3099// This implementation uses NUL-terminated C strings for identities and identity
3100// hints, so values with a NUL character are not supported. (RFC 4279 does not
3101// specify the format of an identity.)
3102
3103// PSK_MAX_IDENTITY_LEN is the maximum supported length of a PSK identity,
3104// excluding the NUL terminator.
3105#define PSK_MAX_IDENTITY_LEN 128
3106
3107// PSK_MAX_PSK_LEN is the maximum supported length of a pre-shared key.
3108#define PSK_MAX_PSK_LEN 256
3109
3110// SSL_CTX_set_psk_client_callback sets the callback to be called when PSK is
3111// negotiated on the client. This callback must be set to enable PSK cipher
3112// suites on the client.
3113//
3114// The callback is passed the identity hint in |hint| or NULL if none was
3115// provided. It should select a PSK identity and write the identity and the
3116// corresponding PSK to |identity| and |psk|, respectively. The identity is
3117// written as a NUL-terminated C string of length (excluding the NUL terminator)
3118// at most |max_identity_len|. The PSK's length must be at most |max_psk_len|.
3119// The callback returns the length of the PSK or 0 if no suitable identity was
3120// found.
3121OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_psk_client_callback(
3122 SSL_CTX *ctx, unsigned (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const char *hint, char *identity,
3123 unsigned max_identity_len, uint8_t *psk,
3124 unsigned max_psk_len));
3125
3126// SSL_set_psk_client_callback sets the callback to be called when PSK is
3127// negotiated on the client. This callback must be set to enable PSK cipher
3128// suites on the client. See also |SSL_CTX_set_psk_client_callback|.
3129OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_psk_client_callback(
3130 SSL *ssl, unsigned (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const char *hint, char *identity,
3131 unsigned max_identity_len, uint8_t *psk,
3132 unsigned max_psk_len));
3133
3134// SSL_CTX_set_psk_server_callback sets the callback to be called when PSK is
3135// negotiated on the server. This callback must be set to enable PSK cipher
3136// suites on the server.
3137//
3138// The callback is passed the identity in |identity|. It should write a PSK of
3139// length at most |max_psk_len| to |psk| and return the number of bytes written
3140// or zero if the PSK identity is unknown.
3141OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_psk_server_callback(
3142 SSL_CTX *ctx, unsigned (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const char *identity, uint8_t *psk,
3143 unsigned max_psk_len));
3144
3145// SSL_set_psk_server_callback sets the callback to be called when PSK is
3146// negotiated on the server. This callback must be set to enable PSK cipher

3148OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_psk_server_callback(
3149 SSL *ssl, unsigned (*cb)(SSL *ssl, const char *identity, uint8_t *psk,
3150 unsigned max_psk_len));

3173// Delegated credentials.
3174//
3175// *** EXPERIMENTAL PRONE TO CHANGE ***
3176//
3177// draft-ietf-tls-subcerts is a proposed extension for TLS 1.3 and above that
3178// allows an end point to use its certificate to delegate credentials for
3179// authentication. If the peer indicates support for this extension, then this
3180// host may use a delegated credential to sign the handshake. Once issued,
3181// credentials can't be revoked. In order to mitigate the damage in case the
3182// credential secret key is compromised, the credential is only valid for a
3183// short time (days, hours, or even minutes). This library implements draft-03
3184// of the protocol spec.
3185//
3186// The extension ID has not been assigned; we're using 0xff02 for the time
3187// being. Currently only the server side is implemented.
3188//
3189// Servers configure a DC for use in the handshake via
3190// |SSL_set1_delegated_credential|. It must be signed by the host's end-entity
3191// certificate as defined in draft-ietf-tls-subcerts-03.
3192
3193// SSL_set1_delegated_credential configures the delegated credential (DC) that
3194// will be sent to the peer for the current connection. |dc| is the DC in wire
3195// format, and |pkey| or |key_method| is the corresponding private key.
3196// Currently (as of draft-03), only servers may configure a DC to use in the
3197// handshake.
3198//
3199// The DC will only be used if the protocol version is correct and the signature
3200// scheme is supported by the peer. If not, the DC will not be negotiated and
3201// the handshake will use the private key (or private key method) associated
3202// with the certificate.
3203OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set1_delegated_credential(
3204 SSL *ssl, CRYPTO_BUFFER *dc, EVP_PKEY *pkey,
3205 const SSL_PRIVATE_KEY_METHOD *key_method);
3206
3207// SSL_delegated_credential_used returns one if a delegated credential was used
3208// and zero otherwise.
3209OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_delegated_credential_used(const SSL *ssl);
3210
3211
3212// QUIC integration.
3213//
3214// QUIC acts as an underlying transport for the TLS 1.3 handshake. The following
3215// functions allow a QUIC implementation to serve as the underlying transport as
3216// described in draft-ietf-quic-tls.
3217//
3218// When configured for QUIC, |SSL_do_handshake| will drive the handshake as
3219// before, but it will not use the configured |BIO|. It will call functions on
3220// |SSL_QUIC_METHOD| to configure secrets and send data. If data is needed from
3221// the peer, it will return |SSL_ERROR_WANT_READ|. As the caller receives data
3222// it can decrypt, it calls |SSL_provide_quic_data|. Subsequent
3223// |SSL_do_handshake| calls will then consume that data and progress the
3224// handshake. After the handshake is complete, the caller should continue to
3225// call |SSL_provide_quic_data| for any post-handshake data, followed by
3226// |SSL_process_quic_post_handshake| to process it. It is an error to call
3227// |SSL_read| and |SSL_write| in QUIC.
3228//
3229// 0-RTT behaves similarly to |TLS_method|'s usual behavior. |SSL_do_handshake|
3230// returns early as soon as the client (respectively, server) is allowed to send
3231// 0-RTT (respectively, half-RTT) data. The caller should then call
3232// |SSL_do_handshake| again to consume the remaining handshake messages and
3233// confirm the handshake. As a client, |SSL_ERROR_EARLY_DATA_REJECTED| and
3234// |SSL_reset_early_data_reject| behave as usual.
3235//
3236// See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-quic-tls-15#section-4.1 for more
3237// details.
3238//
3239// To avoid DoS attacks, the QUIC implementation must limit the amount of data
3240// being queued up. The implementation can call
3241// |SSL_quic_max_handshake_flight_len| to get the maximum buffer length at each
3242// encryption level.
3243//
3244// QUIC implementations must additionally configure transport parameters with
3245// |SSL_set_quic_transport_params|. |SSL_get_peer_quic_transport_params| may be
3246// used to query the value received from the peer. BoringSSL handles this
3247// extension as an opaque byte string. The caller is responsible for serializing
3248// and parsing them. See draft-ietf-quic-transport (section 7.3) for details.
3249//
3250// QUIC additionally imposes restrictions on 0-RTT. In particular, the QUIC
3251// transport layer requires that if a server accepts 0-RTT data, then the
3252// transport parameters sent on the resumed connection must not lower any limits
3253// compared to the transport parameters that the server sent on the connection
3254// where the ticket for 0-RTT was issued. In effect, the server must remember
3255// the transport parameters with the ticket. Application protocols running on
3256// QUIC may impose similar restrictions, for example HTTP/3's restrictions on
3257// SETTINGS frames.
3258//
3259// BoringSSL implements this check by doing a byte-for-byte comparison of an
3260// opaque context passed in by the server. This context must be the same on the
3261// connection where the ticket was issued and the connection where that ticket
3262// is used for 0-RTT. If there is a mismatch, or the context was not set,
3263// BoringSSL will reject early data (but not reject the resumption attempt).
3264// This context is set via |SSL_set_quic_early_data_context| and should cover
3265// both transport parameters and any application state.
3266// |SSL_set_quic_early_data_context| must be called on the server with a
3267// non-empty context if the server is to support 0-RTT in QUIC.
3268//
3269// BoringSSL does not perform any client-side checks on the transport
3270// parameters received from a server that also accepted early data. It is up to
3271// the caller to verify that the received transport parameters do not lower any
3272// limits, and to close the QUIC connection if that is not the case. The same
3273// holds for any application protocol state remembered for 0-RTT, e.g. HTTP/3
3274// SETTINGS.
3275
3276// ssl_encryption_level_t represents a specific QUIC encryption level used to
3277// transmit handshake messages.
3278enum ssl_encryption_level_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
3279 ssl_encryption_initial = 0,
3280 ssl_encryption_early_data,
3281 ssl_encryption_handshake,
3282 ssl_encryption_application,
3283};
3284
3285// ssl_quic_method_st (aka |SSL_QUIC_METHOD|) describes custom QUIC hooks.
3286struct ssl_quic_method_st {
3287 // set_read_secret configures the read secret and cipher suite for the given
3288 // encryption level. It returns one on success and zero to terminate the
3289 // handshake with an error. It will be called at most once per encryption
3290 // level.
3291 //
3292 // BoringSSL will not release read keys before QUIC may use them. Once a level
3293 // has been initialized, QUIC may begin processing data from it. Handshake
3294 // data should be passed to |SSL_provide_quic_data| and application data (if
3295 // |level| is |ssl_encryption_early_data| or |ssl_encryption_application|) may
3296 // be processed according to the rules of the QUIC protocol.
3297 //
3298 // QUIC ACKs packets at the same encryption level they were received at,
3299 // except that client |ssl_encryption_early_data| (0-RTT) packets trigger
3300 // server |ssl_encryption_application| (1-RTT) ACKs. BoringSSL will always
3301 // install ACK-writing keys with |set_write_secret| before the packet-reading
3302 // keys with |set_read_secret|. This ensures the caller can always ACK any
3303 // packet it decrypts. Note this means the server installs 1-RTT write keys
3304 // before 0-RTT read keys.
3305 //
3306 // The converse is not true. An encryption level may be configured with write
3307 // secrets a roundtrip before the corresponding secrets for reading ACKs is
3308 // available.
3309 int (*set_read_secret)(SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level,
3310 const SSL_CIPHER *cipher, const uint8_t *secret,
3311 size_t secret_len);
3312 // set_write_secret behaves like |set_read_secret| but configures the write
3313 // secret and cipher suite for the given encryption level. It will be called
3314 // at most once per encryption level.
3315 //
3316 // BoringSSL will not release write keys before QUIC may use them. If |level|
3317 // is |ssl_encryption_early_data| or |ssl_encryption_application|, QUIC may
3318 // begin sending application data at |level|. However, note that BoringSSL
3319 // configures server |ssl_encryption_application| write keys before the client
3320 // Finished. This allows QUIC to send half-RTT data, but the handshake is not
3321 // confirmed at this point and, if requesting client certificates, the client
3322 // is not yet authenticated.
3323 //
3324 // See |set_read_secret| for additional invariants between packets and their
3325 // ACKs.
3326 //
3327 // Note that, on 0-RTT reject, the |ssl_encryption_early_data| write secret
3328 // may use a different cipher suite from the other keys.
3329 int (*set_write_secret)(SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level,
3330 const SSL_CIPHER *cipher, const uint8_t *secret,
3331 size_t secret_len);
3332 // add_handshake_data adds handshake data to the current flight at the given
3333 // encryption level. It returns one on success and zero on error.
3334 //
3335 // BoringSSL will pack data from a single encryption level together, but a
3336 // single handshake flight may include multiple encryption levels. Callers
3337 // should defer writing data to the network until |flush_flight| to better
3338 // pack QUIC packets into transport datagrams.
3339 //
3340 // If |level| is not |ssl_encryption_initial|, this function will not be
3341 // called before |level| is initialized with |set_write_secret|.
3342 int (*add_handshake_data)(SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level,
3343 const uint8_t *data, size_t len);
3344 // flush_flight is called when the current flight is complete and should be
3345 // written to the transport. Note a flight may contain data at several
3346 // encryption levels. It returns one on success and zero on error.
3347 int (*flush_flight)(SSL *ssl);
3348 // send_alert sends a fatal alert at the specified encryption level. It
3349 // returns one on success and zero on error.
3350 //
3351 // If |level| is not |ssl_encryption_initial|, this function will not be
3352 // called before |level| is initialized with |set_write_secret|.
3353 int (*send_alert)(SSL *ssl, enum ssl_encryption_level_t level, uint8_t alert);
3354};

3434// SETTINGS frame and the QUIC Transport Parameters (except the stateless reset
3435// token).

3438// certificate selection. It returns 1 on success and 0 on failure.

3444// Early data.
3445//
3446// WARNING: 0-RTT support in BoringSSL is currently experimental and not fully
3447// implemented. It may cause interoperability or security failures when used.
3448//
3449// Early data, or 0-RTT, is a feature in TLS 1.3 which allows clients to send
3450// data on the first flight during a resumption handshake. This can save a
3451// round-trip in some application protocols.
3452//
3453// WARNING: A 0-RTT handshake has different security properties from normal
3454// handshake, so it is off by default unless opted in. In particular, early data
3455// is replayable by a network attacker. Callers must account for this when
3456// sending or processing data before the handshake is confirmed. See RFC 8446
3457// for more information.
3458//
3459// As a server, if early data is accepted, |SSL_do_handshake| will complete as
3460// soon as the ClientHello is processed and server flight sent. |SSL_write| may
3461// be used to send half-RTT data. |SSL_read| will consume early data and
3462// transition to 1-RTT data as appropriate. Prior to the transition,
3463// |SSL_in_init| will report the handshake is still in progress. Callers may use
3464// it or |SSL_in_early_data| to defer or reject requests as needed.
3465//
3466// Early data as a client is more complex. If the offered session (see
3467// |SSL_set_session|) is 0-RTT-capable, the handshake will return after sending
3468// the ClientHello. The predicted peer certificates and ALPN protocol will be
3469// available via the usual APIs. |SSL_write| will write early data, up to the
3470// session's limit. Writes past this limit and |SSL_read| will complete the
3471// handshake before continuing. Callers may also call |SSL_do_handshake| again
3472// to complete the handshake sooner.
3473//
3474// If the server accepts early data, the handshake will succeed. |SSL_read| and
3475// |SSL_write| will then act as in a 1-RTT handshake. The peer certificates and
3476// ALPN protocol will be as predicted and need not be re-queried.
3477//
3478// If the server rejects early data, |SSL_do_handshake| (and thus |SSL_read| and
3479// |SSL_write|) will then fail with |SSL_get_error| returning
3480// |SSL_ERROR_EARLY_DATA_REJECTED|. The caller should treat this as a connection
3481// error and most likely perform a high-level retry. Note the server may still
3482// have processed the early data due to attacker replays.
3483//
3484// To then continue the handshake on the original connection, use
3485// |SSL_reset_early_data_reject|. The connection will then behave as one which
3486// had not yet completed the handshake. This allows a faster retry than making a
3487// fresh connection. |SSL_do_handshake| will complete the full handshake,
3488// possibly resulting in different peer certificates, ALPN protocol, and other
3489// properties. The caller must disregard any values from before the reset and
3490// query again.
3491//
3492// Finally, to implement the fallback described in RFC 8446 appendix D.3, retry
3493// on a fresh connection without 0-RTT if the handshake fails with
3494// |SSL_R_WRONG_VERSION_ON_EARLY_DATA|.
3495
3496// SSL_CTX_set_early_data_enabled sets whether early data is allowed to be used
3497// with resumptions using |ctx|.
3498OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_early_data_enabled(SSL_CTX *ctx, int enabled);
3499
3500// SSL_set_early_data_enabled sets whether early data is allowed to be used
3501// with resumptions using |ssl|. See |SSL_CTX_set_early_data_enabled| for more
3502// information.
3503OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_early_data_enabled(SSL *ssl, int enabled);
3504
3505// SSL_in_early_data returns one if |ssl| has a pending handshake that has
3506// progressed enough to send or receive early data. Clients may call |SSL_write|
3507// to send early data, but |SSL_read| will complete the handshake before
3508// accepting application data. Servers may call |SSL_read| to read early data
3509// and |SSL_write| to send half-RTT data.
3510OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_in_early_data(const SSL *ssl);
3511
3512// SSL_SESSION_early_data_capable returns whether early data would have been
3513// attempted with |session| if enabled.
3514OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_SESSION_early_data_capable(const SSL_SESSION *session);
3515
3516// SSL_SESSION_copy_without_early_data returns a copy of |session| with early
3517// data disabled. If |session| already does not support early data, it returns
3518// |session| with the reference count increased. The caller takes ownership of
3519// the result and must release it with |SSL_SESSION_free|.
3520//
3521// This function may be used on the client to clear early data support from
3522// existing sessions when the server rejects early data. In particular,
3523// |SSL_R_WRONG_VERSION_ON_EARLY_DATA| requires a fresh connection to retry, and
3524// the client would not want 0-RTT enabled for the next connection attempt.
3525OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *SSL_SESSION_copy_without_early_data(
3526 SSL_SESSION *session);
3527
3528// SSL_early_data_accepted returns whether early data was accepted on the
3529// handshake performed by |ssl|.
3530OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_early_data_accepted(const SSL *ssl);
3531
3532// SSL_reset_early_data_reject resets |ssl| after an early data reject. All
3533// 0-RTT state is discarded, including any pending |SSL_write| calls. The caller
3534// should treat |ssl| as a logically fresh connection, usually by driving the
3535// handshake to completion using |SSL_do_handshake|.
3536//
3537// It is an error to call this function on an |SSL| object that is not signaling
3538// |SSL_ERROR_EARLY_DATA_REJECTED|.
3539OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_reset_early_data_reject(SSL *ssl);
3540
3541// SSL_get_ticket_age_skew returns the difference, in seconds, between the
3542// client-sent ticket age and the server-computed value in TLS 1.3 server
3543// connections which resumed a session.
3544OPENSSL_EXPORT int32_t SSL_get_ticket_age_skew(const SSL *ssl);
3545
3546// An ssl_early_data_reason_t describes why 0-RTT was accepted or rejected.
3547// These values are persisted to logs. Entries should not be renumbered and
3548// numeric values should never be reused.
3549enum ssl_early_data_reason_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
3550 // The handshake has not progressed far enough for the 0-RTT status to be
3551 // known.
3552 ssl_early_data_unknown = 0,
3553 // 0-RTT is disabled for this connection.
3554 ssl_early_data_disabled = 1,
3555 // 0-RTT was accepted.
3556 ssl_early_data_accepted = 2,
3557 // The negotiated protocol version does not support 0-RTT.
3558 ssl_early_data_protocol_version = 3,
3559 // The peer declined to offer or accept 0-RTT for an unknown reason.
3560 ssl_early_data_peer_declined = 4,
3561 // The client did not offer a session.
3562 ssl_early_data_no_session_offered = 5,
3563 // The server declined to resume the session.
3564 ssl_early_data_session_not_resumed = 6,
3565 // The session does not support 0-RTT.
3566 ssl_early_data_unsupported_for_session = 7,
3567 // The server sent a HelloRetryRequest.
3568 ssl_early_data_hello_retry_request = 8,
3569 // The negotiated ALPN protocol did not match the session.
3570 ssl_early_data_alpn_mismatch = 9,
3571 // The connection negotiated Channel ID, which is incompatible with 0-RTT.
3572 ssl_early_data_channel_id = 10,
3573 // The connection negotiated token binding, which is incompatible with 0-RTT.
3574 ssl_early_data_token_binding = 11,
3575 // The client and server ticket age were too far apart.
3576 ssl_early_data_ticket_age_skew = 12,
3577 // QUIC parameters differ between this connection and the original.
3578 ssl_early_data_quic_parameter_mismatch = 13,
3579 // The application settings did not match the session.
3580 ssl_early_data_alps_mismatch = 14,
3581 // The value of the largest entry.
3582 ssl_early_data_reason_max_value = ssl_early_data_alps_mismatch,
3583};
3584
3585// SSL_get_early_data_reason returns details why 0-RTT was accepted or rejected
3586// on |ssl|. This is primarily useful on the server.
3587OPENSSL_EXPORT enum ssl_early_data_reason_t SSL_get_early_data_reason(
3588 const SSL *ssl);

3590// SSL_early_data_reason_string returns a string representation for |reason|, or
3591// NULL if |reason| is unknown. This function may be used for logging.
3592OPENSSL_EXPORT const char *SSL_early_data_reason_string(
3593 enum ssl_early_data_reason_t reason);

3596// Encrypted ClientHello.
3597//
3598// ECH is a mechanism for encrypting the entire ClientHello message in TLS 1.3.
3599// This can prevent observers from seeing cleartext information about the
3600// connection, such as the server_name extension.
3601//
3602// ECH support in BoringSSL is still experimental and under development.
3603//
3604// See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-tls-esni-09.
3605
3606// SSL_set_enable_ech_grease configures whether the client may send ECH GREASE
3607// as part of this connection.
3608OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_enable_ech_grease(SSL *ssl, int enable);
3609
3610// SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_new returns a newly-allocated
3611// |SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST| or NULL on error.
3612OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST *SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_new(void);
3613
3614// SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_up_ref increments the reference count of |list|.
3615OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_up_ref(
3616 SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST *list);
3617
3618// SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_free releases memory associated with |list|.
3619OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_free(
3620 SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST *list);
3621
3622// SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_add appends an ECHConfig in |ech_config| and its
3623// corresponding private key in |private_key| to |list|. When |is_retry_config|
3624// is non-zero, this config will be returned to the client on configuration
3625// mismatch. It returns one on success and zero on error. See also
3626// |SSL_CTX_set1_ech_server_config_list|.
3627//
3628// This function should be called successively to register each ECHConfig in
3629// decreasing order of preference. This configuration must be completed before
3630// setting |list| on an |SSL_CTX| with |SSL_CTX_set1_ech_server_config_list|.
3631// After that point, |list| is immutable; no more ECHConfig values may be added.
3632OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_add(
3633 SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST *list, int is_retry_config,
3634 const uint8_t *ech_config, size_t ech_config_len,
3635 const uint8_t *private_key, size_t private_key_len);
3636
3637// SSL_CTX_set1_ech_server_config_list atomically sets the refcounted |list|
3638// onto |ctx|, releasing the old list. |SSL| objects associated with |ctx|, as
3639// servers, will use |list| to decrypt incoming encrypted ClientHello messages.
3640// It returns one on success, and zero on failure.
3641//
3642// If |list| does not contain any retry configs, this function will fail. Retry
3643// configs are marked as such when they are added to |list| with
3644// |SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST_add|.
3645//
3646// Once |list| has been passed to this function, it is immutable. Unlike most
3647// |SSL_CTX| configuration functions, this function may be called even if |ctx|
3648// already has associated connections on multiple threads. This may be used to
3649// rotate keys in a long-lived server process.
3650//
3651// The configured ECHConfig values should also be advertised out-of-band via DNS
3652// (see draft-ietf-dnsop-svcb-https). Before advertising an ECHConfig in DNS,
3653// deployments should ensure all instances of the service are configured with
3654// the ECHConfig and corresponding private key.
3655//
3656// Only the most recent fully-deployed ECHConfigs should be advertised in DNS.
3657// |list| may contain a newer set if those ECHConfigs are mid-deployment. It
3658// should also contain older sets, until the DNS change has rolled out and the
3659// old records have expired from caches.
3660//
3661// If there is a mismatch, |SSL| objects associated with |ctx| will complete the
3662// handshake using the cleartext ClientHello and send updated ECHConfig values
3663// to the client. The client will then retry to recover, but with a latency
3664// penalty. This recovery flow depends on the public name in the ECHConfig.
3665// Before advertising an ECHConfig in DNS, deployments must ensure all instances
3666// of the service can present a valid certificate for the public name.
3667//
3668// BoringSSL negotiates ECH before certificate selection callbacks are called,
3669// including |SSL_CTX_set_select_certificate_cb|. If ECH is negotiated, the
3670// reported |SSL_CLIENT_HELLO| structure and |SSL_get_servername| function will
3671// transparently reflect the inner ClientHello. Callers should select parameters
3672// based on these values to correctly handle ECH as well as the recovery flow.
3673OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set1_ech_server_config_list(
3674 SSL_CTX *ctx, SSL_ECH_SERVER_CONFIG_LIST *list);
3675

3677// Alerts.
3678//
3679// TLS uses alerts to signal error conditions. Alerts have a type (warning or
3680// fatal) and description. OpenSSL internally handles fatal alerts with
3681// dedicated error codes (see |SSL_AD_REASON_OFFSET|). Except for close_notify,
3682// warning alerts are silently ignored and may only be surfaced with
3683// |SSL_CTX_set_info_callback|.
3684
3685// SSL_AD_REASON_OFFSET is the offset between error reasons and |SSL_AD_*|
3686// values. Any error code under |ERR_LIB_SSL| with an error reason above this
3687// value corresponds to an alert description. Consumers may add or subtract
3688// |SSL_AD_REASON_OFFSET| to convert between them.
3689//
3690// make_errors.go reserves error codes above 1000 for manually-assigned errors.
3691// This value must be kept in sync with reservedReasonCode in make_errors.h
3692#define SSL_AD_REASON_OFFSET 1000
3693
3694// SSL_AD_* are alert descriptions.
3695#define SSL_AD_CLOSE_NOTIFY SSL3_AD_CLOSE_NOTIFY
3696#define SSL_AD_UNEXPECTED_MESSAGE SSL3_AD_UNEXPECTED_MESSAGE
3697#define SSL_AD_BAD_RECORD_MAC SSL3_AD_BAD_RECORD_MAC
3698#define SSL_AD_DECRYPTION_FAILED TLS1_AD_DECRYPTION_FAILED
3699#define SSL_AD_RECORD_OVERFLOW TLS1_AD_RECORD_OVERFLOW
3700#define SSL_AD_DECOMPRESSION_FAILURE SSL3_AD_DECOMPRESSION_FAILURE
3701#define SSL_AD_HANDSHAKE_FAILURE SSL3_AD_HANDSHAKE_FAILURE
3702#define SSL_AD_NO_CERTIFICATE SSL3_AD_NO_CERTIFICATE // Legacy SSL 3.0 value
3703#define SSL_AD_BAD_CERTIFICATE SSL3_AD_BAD_CERTIFICATE
3704#define SSL_AD_UNSUPPORTED_CERTIFICATE SSL3_AD_UNSUPPORTED_CERTIFICATE
3705#define SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_REVOKED SSL3_AD_CERTIFICATE_REVOKED
3706#define SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_EXPIRED SSL3_AD_CERTIFICATE_EXPIRED
3707#define SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_UNKNOWN SSL3_AD_CERTIFICATE_UNKNOWN
3708#define SSL_AD_ILLEGAL_PARAMETER SSL3_AD_ILLEGAL_PARAMETER
3709#define SSL_AD_UNKNOWN_CA TLS1_AD_UNKNOWN_CA
3710#define SSL_AD_ACCESS_DENIED TLS1_AD_ACCESS_DENIED
3711#define SSL_AD_DECODE_ERROR TLS1_AD_DECODE_ERROR
3712#define SSL_AD_DECRYPT_ERROR TLS1_AD_DECRYPT_ERROR
3713#define SSL_AD_EXPORT_RESTRICTION TLS1_AD_EXPORT_RESTRICTION
3714#define SSL_AD_PROTOCOL_VERSION TLS1_AD_PROTOCOL_VERSION
3715#define SSL_AD_INSUFFICIENT_SECURITY TLS1_AD_INSUFFICIENT_SECURITY
3716#define SSL_AD_INTERNAL_ERROR TLS1_AD_INTERNAL_ERROR
3717#define SSL_AD_INAPPROPRIATE_FALLBACK SSL3_AD_INAPPROPRIATE_FALLBACK
3718#define SSL_AD_USER_CANCELLED TLS1_AD_USER_CANCELLED
3719#define SSL_AD_NO_RENEGOTIATION TLS1_AD_NO_RENEGOTIATION
3720#define SSL_AD_MISSING_EXTENSION TLS1_AD_MISSING_EXTENSION
3721#define SSL_AD_UNSUPPORTED_EXTENSION TLS1_AD_UNSUPPORTED_EXTENSION
3722#define SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_UNOBTAINABLE TLS1_AD_CERTIFICATE_UNOBTAINABLE
3723#define SSL_AD_UNRECOGNIZED_NAME TLS1_AD_UNRECOGNIZED_NAME
3724#define SSL_AD_BAD_CERTIFICATE_STATUS_RESPONSE \
3725 TLS1_AD_BAD_CERTIFICATE_STATUS_RESPONSE
3726#define SSL_AD_BAD_CERTIFICATE_HASH_VALUE TLS1_AD_BAD_CERTIFICATE_HASH_VALUE
3727#define SSL_AD_UNKNOWN_PSK_IDENTITY TLS1_AD_UNKNOWN_PSK_IDENTITY
3728#define SSL_AD_CERTIFICATE_REQUIRED TLS1_AD_CERTIFICATE_REQUIRED
3729#define SSL_AD_NO_APPLICATION_PROTOCOL TLS1_AD_NO_APPLICATION_PROTOCOL
3730
3731// SSL_alert_type_string_long returns a string description of |value| as an
3732// alert type (warning or fatal).
3733OPENSSL_EXPORT const char *SSL_alert_type_string_long(int value);

3735// SSL_alert_desc_string_long returns a string description of |value| as an
3736// alert description or "unknown" if unknown.
3737OPENSSL_EXPORT const char *SSL_alert_desc_string_long(int value);

3739// SSL_send_fatal_alert sends a fatal alert over |ssl| of the specified type,
3740// which should be one of the |SSL_AD_*| constants. It returns one on success

3791// to call this function during a handshake.

3793

3795// current connection state. It is an error to call this function during a
3796// handshake.
3797OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_generate_key_block(const SSL *ssl, uint8_t *out,
3798 size_t out_len);

3801// next incoming record in the current epoch. In DTLS, it returns the maximum

3808// two most significant bytes.
3809OPENSSL_EXPORT uint64_t SSL_get_write_sequence(const SSL *ssl);
3810
3811
3812// Handshake hints.
3813//
3814// *** EXPERIMENTAL DO NOT USE WITHOUT CHECKING ***
3815//
3816// Some server deployments make asynchronous RPC calls in both ClientHello
3817// dispatch and private key operations. In TLS handshakes where the private key
3818// operation occurs in the first round-trip, this results in two consecutive RPC
3819// round-trips. Handshake hints allow the RPC service to predicte a signature.
3820// If correctly predicted, this can skip the second RPC call.
3821//
3822// First, the server installs a certificate selection callback (see
3823// |SSL_CTX_set_select_certificate_cb|). When that is called, it performs the
3824// RPC as before, but includes the ClientHello and a capabilities string from
3825// |SSL_serialize_capabilities|.
3826//
3827// Next, the RPC service creates its own |SSL| object, applies the results of
3828// certificate selection, calls |SSL_request_handshake_hints|, and runs the
3829// handshake. If this successfully computes handshake hints (see
3830// |SSL_serialize_handshake_hints|), the RPC server should send the hints
3831// alongside any certificate selection results.
3832//
3833// Finally, the server calls |SSL_set_handshake_hints| and applies any
3834// configuration from the RPC server. It then completes the handshake as before.
3835// If the hints apply, BoringSSL will use the predicted signature and skip the
3836// private key callbacks. Otherwise, BoringSSL will call private key callbacks
3837// to generate a signature as before.
3838//
3839// Callers should synchronize configuration across the two services.
3840// Configuration mismatches and some cases of version skew are not fatal, but
3841// may result in the hints not applying. Additionally, some handshake flows use
3842// the private key in later round-trips, such as TLS 1.3 HelloRetryRequest. In
3843// those cases, BoringSSL will not predict a signature as there is no benefit.
3844// Callers must allow for handshakes to complete without a predicted signature.
3845//
3846// For now, only TLS 1.3 is hinted. TLS 1.2 will work, but the hints will be
3847// empty.
3848
3849// SSL_serialize_capabilities writes an opaque byte string to |out| describing
3850// some of |ssl|'s capabilities. It returns one on success and zero on error.
3851//
3852// This string is used by BoringSSL internally to reduce the impact of version
3853// skew.
3854OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_serialize_capabilities(const SSL *ssl, CBB *out);
3855
3856// SSL_request_handshake_hints configures |ssl| to generate a handshake hint for
3857// |client_hello|. It returns one on success and zero on error. |client_hello|
3858// should contain a serialized ClientHello structure, from the |client_hello|
3859// and |client_hello_len| fields of the |SSL_CLIENT_HELLO| structure.
3860// |capabilities| should contain the output of |SSL_serialize_capabilities|.
3861//
3862// When configured, |ssl| will perform no I/O (so there is no need to configure
3863// |BIO|s). For QUIC, the caller should still configure an |SSL_QUIC_METHOD|,
3864// but the callbacks themselves will never be called and may be left NULL or
3865// report failure. |SSL_provide_quic_data| also should not be called.
3866//
3867// If hint generation is successful, |SSL_do_handshake| will stop the handshake
3868// early with |SSL_get_error| returning |SSL_ERROR_HANDSHAKE_HINTS_READY|. At
3869// this point, the caller should run |SSL_serialize_handshake_hints| to extract
3870// the resulting hints.
3871//
3872// Hint generation may fail if, e.g., |ssl| was unable to process the
3873// ClientHello. Callers should then complete the certificate selection RPC and
3874// continue the original handshake with no hint. It will likely fail, but this
3875// reports the correct alert to the client and is more robust in case of
3876// mismatch.
3877OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_request_handshake_hints(SSL *ssl,
3878 const uint8_t *client_hello,
3879 size_t client_hello_len,
3880 const uint8_t *capabilities,
3881 size_t capabilities_len);
3882
3883// SSL_serialize_handshake_hints writes an opaque byte string to |out|
3884// containing the handshake hints computed by |out|. It returns one on success
3885// and zero on error. This function should only be called if
3886// |SSL_request_handshake_hints| was configured and the handshake terminated
3887// with |SSL_ERROR_HANDSHAKE_HINTS_READY|.
3888//
3889// This string may be passed to |SSL_set_handshake_hints| on another |SSL| to
3890// avoid an extra signature call.
3891OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_serialize_handshake_hints(const SSL *ssl, CBB *out);
3892
3893// SSL_set_handshake_hints configures |ssl| to use |hints| as handshake hints.
3894// It returns one on success and zero on error. The handshake will then continue
3895// as before, but apply predicted values from |hints| where applicable.
3896//
3897// Hints may contain connection and session secrets, so they must not leak and
3898// must come from a source trusted to terminate the connection. However, they
3899// will not change |ssl|'s configuration. The caller is responsible for
3900// serializing and applying options from the RPC server as needed. This ensures
3901// |ssl|'s behavior is self-consistent and consistent with the caller's local
3902// decisions.
3903OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_handshake_hints(SSL *ssl, const uint8_t *hints,
3904 size_t hints_len);

3909// SSL_CTX_set_msg_callback installs |cb| as the message callback for |ctx|.
3910// This callback will be called when sending or receiving low-level record
3911// headers, complete handshake messages, ChangeCipherSpec, and alerts.
3912// |write_p| is one for outgoing messages and zero for incoming messages.
3913//
3914// For each record header, |cb| is called with |version| = 0 and |content_type|
3915// = |SSL3_RT_HEADER|. The |len| bytes from |buf| contain the header. Note that
3916// this does not include the record body. If the record is sealed, the length
3917// in the header is the length of the ciphertext.
3918//
3919// For each handshake message, ChangeCipherSpec, and alert, |version| is the
3920// protocol version and |content_type| is the corresponding record type. The
3921// |len| bytes from |buf| contain the handshake message, one-byte
3922// ChangeCipherSpec body, and two-byte alert, respectively.
3923//
3924// For a V2ClientHello, |version| is |SSL2_VERSION|, |content_type| is zero, and
3925// the |len| bytes from |buf| contain the V2ClientHello structure.
3926OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_msg_callback(
3927 SSL_CTX *ctx, void (*cb)(int write_p, int version, int content_type,
3928 const void *buf, size_t len, SSL *ssl, void *arg));
3929
3930// SSL_CTX_set_msg_callback_arg sets the |arg| parameter of the message
3931// callback.
3932OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_msg_callback_arg(SSL_CTX *ctx, void *arg);
3933
3934// SSL_set_msg_callback installs |cb| as the message callback of |ssl|. See
3935// |SSL_CTX_set_msg_callback| for when this callback is called.
3936OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_msg_callback(
3937 SSL *ssl, void (*cb)(int write_p, int version, int content_type,
3938 const void *buf, size_t len, SSL *ssl, void *arg));
3939
3940// SSL_set_msg_callback_arg sets the |arg| parameter of the message callback.
3941OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_msg_callback_arg(SSL *ssl, void *arg);
3942
3943// SSL_CTX_set_keylog_callback configures a callback to log key material. This
3944// is intended for debugging use with tools like Wireshark. The |cb| function
3945// should log |line| followed by a newline, synchronizing with any concurrent
3946// access to the log.
3947//
3948// The format is described in
3949// https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/Key_Log_Format.
3950OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_keylog_callback(

3958// SSL_CTX_set_current_time_cb configures a callback to retrieve the current
3959// time, which should be set in |*out_clock|. This can be used for testing
3960// purposes; for example, a callback can be configured that returns a time
3961// set explicitly by the test. The |ssl| pointer passed to |cb| is always null.
3962OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_current_time_cb(

3965// SSL_set_shed_handshake_config allows some of the configuration of |ssl| to be
3966// freed after its handshake completes. Once configuration has been shed, APIs
3967// that query it may fail. "Configuration" in this context means anything that
3968// was set by the caller, as distinct from information derived from the
3969// handshake. For example, |SSL_get_ciphers| queries how the |SSL| was
3970// configured by the caller, and fails after configuration has been shed,
3971// whereas |SSL_get_cipher| queries the result of the handshake, and is
3972// unaffected by configuration shedding.
3973//
3974// If configuration shedding is enabled, it is an error to call |SSL_clear|.
3975//
3976// Note that configuration shedding as a client additionally depends on
3977// renegotiation being disabled (see |SSL_set_renegotiate_mode|). If
3978// renegotiation is possible, the configuration will be retained. If
3979// configuration shedding is enabled and renegotiation later disabled after the
3980// handshake, |SSL_set_renegotiate_mode| will shed configuration then. This may
3981// be useful for clients which support renegotiation with some ALPN protocols,
3982// such as HTTP/1.1, and not others, such as HTTP/2.
3983OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_shed_handshake_config(SSL *ssl, int enable);

3985enum ssl_renegotiate_mode_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT {
3986 ssl_renegotiate_never = 0,
3987 ssl_renegotiate_once,
3988 ssl_renegotiate_freely,
3989 ssl_renegotiate_ignore,
3990 ssl_renegotiate_explicit,
3991};
3992
3993// SSL_set_renegotiate_mode configures how |ssl|, a client, reacts to
3994// renegotiation attempts by a server. If |ssl| is a server, peer-initiated
3995// renegotiations are *always* rejected and this function does nothing.
3996//
3997// The renegotiation mode defaults to |ssl_renegotiate_never|, but may be set
3998// at any point in a connection's lifetime. Set it to |ssl_renegotiate_once| to
3999// allow one renegotiation, |ssl_renegotiate_freely| to allow all
4000// renegotiations or |ssl_renegotiate_ignore| to ignore HelloRequest messages.
4001// Note that ignoring HelloRequest messages may cause the connection to stall
4002// if the server waits for the renegotiation to complete.
4003//
4004// If set to |ssl_renegotiate_explicit|, |SSL_read| and |SSL_peek| calls which
4005// encounter a HelloRequest will pause with |SSL_ERROR_WANT_RENEGOTIATE|.
4006// |SSL_write| will continue to work while paused. The caller may call
4007// |SSL_renegotiate| to begin the renegotiation at a later point. This mode may
4008// be used if callers wish to eagerly call |SSL_peek| without triggering a
4009// renegotiation.
4010//
4011// If configuration shedding is enabled (see |SSL_set_shed_handshake_config|),
4012// configuration is released if, at any point after the handshake, renegotiation
4013// is disabled. It is not possible to switch from disabling renegotiation to
4014// enabling it on a given connection. Callers that condition renegotiation on,
4015// e.g., ALPN must enable renegotiation before the handshake and conditionally
4016// disable it afterwards.
4017//
4018// There is no support in BoringSSL for initiating renegotiations as a client
4019// or server.
4020OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_renegotiate_mode(SSL *ssl,
4021 enum ssl_renegotiate_mode_t mode);
4022
4023// SSL_renegotiate starts a deferred renegotiation on |ssl| if it was configured
4024// with |ssl_renegotiate_explicit| and has a pending HelloRequest. It returns
4025// one on success and zero on error.
4026//
4027// This function does not do perform any I/O. On success, a subsequent
4028// |SSL_do_handshake| call will run the handshake. |SSL_write| and
4029// |SSL_read| will also complete the handshake before sending or receiving
4030// application data.
4031OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_renegotiate(SSL *ssl);
4032
4033// SSL_renegotiate_pending returns one if |ssl| is in the middle of a
4034// renegotiation.
4035OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_renegotiate_pending(SSL *ssl);
4036
4037// SSL_total_renegotiations returns the total number of renegotiation handshakes
4038// performed by |ssl|. This includes the pending renegotiation, if any.
4039OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_total_renegotiations(const SSL *ssl);

4159// SSL_ST_* are possible values for |SSL_state|, the bitmasks that make them up,
4160// and some historical values for compatibility. Only |SSL_ST_INIT| and
4161// |SSL_ST_OK| are ever returned.
4162#define SSL_ST_CONNECT 0x1000
4163#define SSL_ST_ACCEPT 0x2000
4164#define SSL_ST_MASK 0x0FFF
4165#define SSL_ST_INIT (SSL_ST_CONNECT | SSL_ST_ACCEPT)
4166#define SSL_ST_OK 0x03
4167#define SSL_ST_RENEGOTIATE (0x04 | SSL_ST_INIT)
4168#define SSL_ST_BEFORE (0x05 | SSL_ST_INIT)
4169
4170// TLS_ST_* are aliases for |SSL_ST_*| for OpenSSL 1.1.0 compatibility.
4171#define TLS_ST_OK SSL_ST_OK
4172#define TLS_ST_BEFORE SSL_ST_BEFORE
4173
4174// SSL_CB_* are possible values for the |type| parameter in the info
4175// callback and the bitmasks that make them up.
4176#define SSL_CB_LOOP 0x01
4177#define SSL_CB_EXIT 0x02
4178#define SSL_CB_READ 0x04
4179#define SSL_CB_WRITE 0x08
4180#define SSL_CB_ALERT 0x4000
4181#define SSL_CB_READ_ALERT (SSL_CB_ALERT | SSL_CB_READ)
4182#define SSL_CB_WRITE_ALERT (SSL_CB_ALERT | SSL_CB_WRITE)
4183#define SSL_CB_ACCEPT_LOOP (SSL_ST_ACCEPT | SSL_CB_LOOP)
4184#define SSL_CB_ACCEPT_EXIT (SSL_ST_ACCEPT | SSL_CB_EXIT)
4185#define SSL_CB_CONNECT_LOOP (SSL_ST_CONNECT | SSL_CB_LOOP)
4186#define SSL_CB_CONNECT_EXIT (SSL_ST_CONNECT | SSL_CB_EXIT)
4187#define SSL_CB_HANDSHAKE_START 0x10
4188#define SSL_CB_HANDSHAKE_DONE 0x20
4189
4190// SSL_CTX_set_info_callback configures a callback to be run when various
4191// events occur during a connection's lifetime. The |type| argument determines
4192// the type of event and the meaning of the |value| argument. Callbacks must
4193// ignore unexpected |type| values.
4194//
4195// |SSL_CB_READ_ALERT| is signaled for each alert received, warning or fatal.
4196// The |value| argument is a 16-bit value where the alert level (either
4197// |SSL3_AL_WARNING| or |SSL3_AL_FATAL|) is in the most-significant eight bits
4198// and the alert type (one of |SSL_AD_*|) is in the least-significant eight.
4199//
4200// |SSL_CB_WRITE_ALERT| is signaled for each alert sent. The |value| argument
4201// is constructed as with |SSL_CB_READ_ALERT|.
4202//
4203// |SSL_CB_HANDSHAKE_START| is signaled when a handshake begins. The |value|
4204// argument is always one.
4205//
4206// |SSL_CB_HANDSHAKE_DONE| is signaled when a handshake completes successfully.
4207// The |value| argument is always one. If a handshake False Starts, this event
4208// may be used to determine when the Finished message is received.
4209//
4210// The following event types expose implementation details of the handshake
4211// state machine. Consuming them is deprecated.
4212//
4213// |SSL_CB_ACCEPT_LOOP| (respectively, |SSL_CB_CONNECT_LOOP|) is signaled when
4214// a server (respectively, client) handshake progresses. The |value| argument
4215// is always one.
4216//
4217// |SSL_CB_ACCEPT_EXIT| (respectively, |SSL_CB_CONNECT_EXIT|) is signaled when
4218// a server (respectively, client) handshake completes, fails, or is paused.
4219// The |value| argument is one if the handshake succeeded and <= 0
4220// otherwise.
4221OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_info_callback(
4222 SSL_CTX *ctx, void (*cb)(const SSL *ssl, int type, int value));
4223
4224// SSL_CTX_get_info_callback returns the callback set by
4225// |SSL_CTX_set_info_callback|.
4226OPENSSL_EXPORT void (*SSL_CTX_get_info_callback(SSL_CTX *ctx))(const SSL *ssl,
4227 int type,
4228 int value);
4229
4230// SSL_set_info_callback configures a callback to be run at various events
4231// during a connection's lifetime. See |SSL_CTX_set_info_callback|.
4232OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_info_callback(
4233 SSL *ssl, void (*cb)(const SSL *ssl, int type, int value));
4234
4235// SSL_get_info_callback returns the callback set by |SSL_set_info_callback|.
4236OPENSSL_EXPORT void (*SSL_get_info_callback(const SSL *ssl))(const SSL *ssl,
4237 int type,
4238 int value);

4491// i2d_SSL_SESSION serializes |in| to the bytes pointed to by |*pp|. On success,
4492// it returns the number of bytes written and advances |*pp| by that many bytes.
4493// On failure, it returns -1. If |pp| is NULL, no bytes are written and only the
4494// length is returned.
4495//
4496// Use |SSL_SESSION_to_bytes| instead.
4497OPENSSL_EXPORT int i2d_SSL_SESSION(SSL_SESSION *in, uint8_t **pp);
4498
4499// d2i_SSL_SESSION parses a serialized session from the |length| bytes pointed
4500// to by |*pp|. It returns the new |SSL_SESSION| and advances |*pp| by the
4501// number of bytes consumed on success and NULL on failure. The caller takes
4502// ownership of the new session and must call |SSL_SESSION_free| when done.
4503//
4504// If |a| is non-NULL, |*a| is released and set the new |SSL_SESSION|.
4505//
4506// Use |SSL_SESSION_from_bytes| instead.
4507OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *d2i_SSL_SESSION(SSL_SESSION **a, const uint8_t **pp,
4508 long length);
4509
4510// i2d_SSL_SESSION_bio serializes |session| and writes the result to |bio|. It
4511// returns the number of bytes written on success and <= 0 on error.
4512OPENSSL_EXPORT int i2d_SSL_SESSION_bio(BIO *bio, const SSL_SESSION *session);
4513
4514// d2i_SSL_SESSION_bio reads a serialized |SSL_SESSION| from |bio| and returns a
4515// newly-allocated |SSL_SESSION| or NULL on error. If |out| is not NULL, it also
4516// frees |*out| and sets |*out| to the new |SSL_SESSION|.
4517OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *d2i_SSL_SESSION_bio(BIO *bio, SSL_SESSION **out);

4564// SSL_CTX_set1_sigalgs takes |num_values| ints and interprets them as pairs
4565// where the first is the nid of a hash function and the second is an
4566// |EVP_PKEY_*| value. It configures the signature algorithm preferences for
4567// |ctx| based on them and returns one on success or zero on error.
4568//
4569// This API is compatible with OpenSSL. However, BoringSSL-specific code should
4570// prefer |SSL_CTX_set_signing_algorithm_prefs| because it's clearer and it's
4571// more convenient to codesearch for specific algorithm values.
4572OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set1_sigalgs(SSL_CTX *ctx, const int *values,
4573 size_t num_values);
4574
4575// SSL_set1_sigalgs takes |num_values| ints and interprets them as pairs where
4576// the first is the nid of a hash function and the second is an |EVP_PKEY_*|
4577// value. It configures the signature algorithm preferences for |ssl| based on
4578// them and returns one on success or zero on error.
4579//
4580// This API is compatible with OpenSSL. However, BoringSSL-specific code should
4581// prefer |SSL_CTX_set_signing_algorithm_prefs| because it's clearer and it's
4582// more convenient to codesearch for specific algorithm values.
4583OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set1_sigalgs(SSL *ssl, const int *values,
4584 size_t num_values);
4585
4586// SSL_CTX_set1_sigalgs_list takes a textual specification of a set of signature
4587// algorithms and configures them on |ctx|. It returns one on success and zero
4588// on error. See
4589// https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.1.0/man3/SSL_CTX_set1_sigalgs_list.html for
4590// a description of the text format. Also note that TLS 1.3 names (e.g.
4591// "rsa_pkcs1_md5_sha1") can also be used (as in OpenSSL, although OpenSSL
4592// doesn't document that).
4593//
4594// This API is compatible with OpenSSL. However, BoringSSL-specific code should
4595// prefer |SSL_CTX_set_signing_algorithm_prefs| because it's clearer and it's
4596// more convenient to codesearch for specific algorithm values.
4597OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set1_sigalgs_list(SSL_CTX *ctx, const char *str);
4598
4599// SSL_set1_sigalgs_list takes a textual specification of a set of signature
4600// algorithms and configures them on |ssl|. It returns one on success and zero
4601// on error. See
4602// https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.1.0/man3/SSL_CTX_set1_sigalgs_list.html for
4603// a description of the text format. Also note that TLS 1.3 names (e.g.
4604// "rsa_pkcs1_md5_sha1") can also be used (as in OpenSSL, although OpenSSL
4605// doesn't document that).
4606//
4607// This API is compatible with OpenSSL. However, BoringSSL-specific code should
4608// prefer |SSL_CTX_set_signing_algorithm_prefs| because it's clearer and it's
4609// more convenient to codesearch for specific algorithm values.
4610OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set1_sigalgs_list(SSL *ssl, const char *str);

4693// SSL_CTX_set_client_cert_cb sets a callback which is called on the client if
4694// the server requests a client certificate and none is configured. On success,
4695// the callback should return one and set |*out_x509| to |*out_pkey| to a leaf
4696// certificate and private key, respectively, passing ownership. It should
4697// return zero to send no certificate and -1 to fail or pause the handshake. If
4698// the handshake is paused, |SSL_get_error| will return
4699// |SSL_ERROR_WANT_X509_LOOKUP|.
4700//
4701// The callback may call |SSL_get0_certificate_types| and
4702// |SSL_get_client_CA_list| for information on the server's certificate request.
4703//
4704// Use |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb| instead. Configuring intermediate certificates with
4705// this function is confusing. This callback may not be registered concurrently
4706// with |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb| or |SSL_set_cert_cb|.
4707OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_CTX_set_client_cert_cb(
4708 SSL_CTX *ctx, int (*cb)(SSL *ssl, X509 **out_x509, EVP_PKEY **out_pkey));

4801// SSL_set_shutdown causes |ssl| to behave as if the shutdown bitmask (see
4802// |SSL_get_shutdown|) were |mode|. This may be used to skip sending or
4803// receiving close_notify in |SSL_shutdown| by causing the implementation to
4804// believe the events already happened.
4805//
4806// It is an error to use |SSL_set_shutdown| to unset a bit that has already been
4807// set. Doing so will trigger an |assert| in debug builds and otherwise be
4808// ignored.
4809//
4810// Use |SSL_CTX_set_quiet_shutdown| instead.
4811OPENSSL_EXPORT void SSL_set_shutdown(SSL *ssl, int mode);

4859// SSL_get_session returns a non-owning pointer to |ssl|'s session. For
4860// historical reasons, which session it returns depends on |ssl|'s state.
4861//
4862// Prior to the start of the initial handshake, it returns the session the
4863// caller set with |SSL_set_session|. After the initial handshake has finished
4864// and if no additional handshakes are in progress, it returns the currently
4865// active session. Its behavior is undefined while a handshake is in progress.
4866//
4867// If trying to add new sessions to an external session cache, use
4868// |SSL_CTX_sess_set_new_cb| instead. In particular, using the callback is
4869// required as of TLS 1.3. For compatibility, this function will return an
4870// unresumable session which may be cached, but will never be resumed.
4871//
4872// If querying properties of the connection, use APIs on the |SSL| object.
4873OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *SSL_get_session(const SSL *ssl);
4874
4875// SSL_get0_session is an alias for |SSL_get_session|.
4876#define SSL_get0_session SSL_get_session
4877
4878// SSL_get1_session acts like |SSL_get_session| but returns a new reference to
4879// the session.
4880OPENSSL_EXPORT SSL_SESSION *SSL_get1_session(SSL *ssl);

4897// |type| is |TLSEXT_STATUSTYPE_ocsp| and disables it otherwise. It returns one
4898// on success and zero if handshake configuration has already been shed.
4899//
4900// Use |SSL_enable_ocsp_stapling| instead.
4901OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_tlsext_status_type(SSL *ssl, int type);
4902
4903// SSL_get_tlsext_status_type returns |TLSEXT_STATUSTYPE_ocsp| if the client
4904// requested OCSP stapling and |TLSEXT_STATUSTYPE_nothing| otherwise. On the
4905// client, this reflects whether OCSP stapling was enabled via, e.g.,
4906// |SSL_set_tlsext_status_type|. On the server, this is determined during the
4907// handshake. It may be queried in callbacks set by |SSL_CTX_set_cert_cb|. The
4908// result is undefined after the handshake completes.
4909OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_get_tlsext_status_type(const SSL *ssl);
4910
4911// SSL_set_tlsext_status_ocsp_resp sets the OCSP response. It returns one on
4912// success and zero on error. On success, |ssl| takes ownership of |resp|, which
4913// must have been allocated by |OPENSSL_malloc|.
4914//
4915// Use |SSL_set_ocsp_response| instead.
4916OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_set_tlsext_status_ocsp_resp(SSL *ssl, uint8_t *resp,
4917 size_t resp_len);
4918
4919// SSL_get_tlsext_status_ocsp_resp sets |*out| to point to the OCSP response
4920// from the server. It returns the length of the response. If there was no
4921// response, it sets |*out| to NULL and returns zero.
4922//
4923// Use |SSL_get0_ocsp_response| instead.
4924//
4925// WARNING: the returned data is not guaranteed to be well formed.
4926OPENSSL_EXPORT size_t SSL_get_tlsext_status_ocsp_resp(const SSL *ssl,
4927 const uint8_t **out);
4928
4929// SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_status_cb configures the legacy OpenSSL OCSP callback and
4930// returns one. Though the type signature is the same, this callback has
4931// different behavior for client and server connections:
4932//
4933// For clients, the callback is called after certificate verification. It should
4934// return one for success, zero for a bad OCSP response, and a negative number
4935// for internal error. Instead, handle this as part of certificate verification.
4936// (Historically, OpenSSL verified certificates just before parsing stapled OCSP
4937// responses, but BoringSSL fixes this ordering. All server credentials are
4938// available during verification.)
4939//
4940// Do not use this callback as a server. It is provided for compatibility
4941// purposes only. For servers, it is called to configure server credentials. It
4942// should return |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_OK| on success, |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_NOACK| to
4943// ignore OCSP requests, or |SSL_TLSEXT_ERR_ALERT_FATAL| on error. It is usually
4944// used to fetch OCSP responses on demand, which is not ideal. Instead, treat
4945// OCSP responses like other server credentials, such as certificates or SCT
4946// lists. Configure, store, and refresh them eagerly. This avoids downtime if
4947// the CA's OCSP responder is briefly offline.
4948OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_status_cb(SSL_CTX *ctx,
4949 int (*callback)(SSL *ssl,
4950 void *arg));
4951
4952// SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_status_arg sets additional data for
4953// |SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_status_cb|'s callback and returns one.
4954OPENSSL_EXPORT int SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_status_arg(SSL_CTX *ctx, void *arg);
